Forgive me you bright Starrs, and doe not frowne that I have not attended as became one that muſt live by your kind Influence. Not yet appeere? ſhee did command I ſhould with confidence expect her; Ha! what's heere? this Character was not viſible before;
" That man's too much compos'd of phlegme
" Will looſe his Miſtreſſe, for a dreame.
Tis hers. I know ſhee has ben heere; Oh fatall! and findinge me a ſleepe ſcorn'd to uncharme my dull and curſed ſilence, this diſtracts mee. Have I ſo long, with ſo much Art and Study labourd this hower and obtain'd, what my ambition look'd at, her conſent, and when the tree itſelfe bow'd downe Its goulden fruit and tempted me to gather, muſt I make my ſelfe uncapable & bee guiltie of ſo black ſo baſe a forfeite? I could teare my eye lidds off, that durſt let in a miſt ſo darke and ſo deſtroyinge: muſt I ſleepe at ſuch a time? that the devill muſt bee over watch'd too? this howre hath blaſted ſuch a hope as the Earth never teem'd with nor the ſpringe gave up in ſmiling bloſſoms to the breath of thoſe ſweete winds that whiſper from the weſt, a tale of triumph to the yeare, I could diſſolve, with curſinge of my Le • hargie. How ſhall I looke upon her face, whoſe love and bold adventure I have thus rewarded? but paſſion will not cure my wounde which muſt bleede till I ſee her, and then either ceaſſe bleſſed by her pardon; or diſmiſſe a life though juſt, too poore a ſacrifice to her Anger. Where ſhall I hide my ſelfe and ſhame for ever? Exit.

div.head: Actus quintus. Scaena prima.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: I cannot forgett my careleſſe Gentleman; his neglect & reproches have wrought ſtrangly upon me; hee's heere.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Is there not a weazle crept in to your chamber, Lady.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: A weazle Sir?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Yes, a Monſieur ſuckegg.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: Doe you take my chamber for a hens neſt, Sir?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Ther's a Thinge that calls him ſelfe Device, one that will break the heart of a poſt-horſe to continue a hand gallop with him, your a la mode, your fightinge fayrie, fethered footed ſervant, when ſaw you him?

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: My fightinge ſervant, has hee beaten you Sir? perhapps hee thought you were his rivall: ſurely I ſaw him not ſince yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Be'e Lady how many mile is it to the next Cutler? the rogue has pawnd or ſold my ſworde.

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: Doe you heare Sir? I can tell you now what Lady; it was you did abuſe ſo

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I abuſe a Lady? Tell me the ſlave reported it; I hope it will prove this Monſieur if ere wee meete againe;—Who was it?

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p:
Vpon condition Sir you will requite
me but with one Gentle favour.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Any thinge.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: You muſt ſit downe and heare me then, while lat a diſtance, thus deliver.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Tis more ſtate.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: I am moſt unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: For what deare Damoſell?

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: And wrong d by a Gentleman I lou'd.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Can hee bee a Gentleman that dares wronge ſo much love and beautie? what s the offence?

sp.speaker: Sist.
sp.p: He will not love againe.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: And you would have the ſtubborne man corrected?

sp.speaker: Siſt
sp.p: I would bee revenged, if I know how, and honour him, ſhould doe me • uſtice.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Name the man: I'le doe it.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: I cannot.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: How.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: Yet turne your face: alas! it is your ſelfe: I have your word to puniſh him.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Sweete Lady I am well acquainted wi • h the worthy Gentleman, but will not kill nor ſtrike him: for I know hee has juſt reaſon not to love you, you, of all your ſexe; hee told mee ſo.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: His reaſon?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
Was in theſe words, ſuppoſe you heare him ſpeake it. Now doe you ſit; Lady; when I conſider you to a perfect forme of what we can call handſ • me with all your attributes of ſoule and body where no Addition or detraction can by cupids, • icer critticks finde a fault, or Mercury with your
eternall frame & then conſider what a thinge I am to this high Character of you; ſo low ſo loſt to noble merits, I diſpaire to love a Miſtreſſe cannot love againe.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: This is as much diſſembled modeſty.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: No let it all alone, I have other reaſons, Lady, among my papers, to love, or to bee in loue is to bee gull'd, that's the plaine Engliſh of cupids latine beſides, all reverence to the calling, I have vowed never to marry: and you know, loue may bringe a man to▪t at laſt and therefore my fine gewgaw, doe not abuſe me.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: How can I when you will neither loue me nor marry mee?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I was not made for a husband.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: But I would make you.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I know what you would make me.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Monſieur Device if you bee alone would preſent his ſervice to you.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Is hee come?

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: Doe me but one favour, I'le recant my loue, I will not have ſo much as one good thought of you, I will neglect you, Sir, but for three minutes.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I'le have patience ſo long. He • hides.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: Admit him. I will bee revenged on ſomebody? now Sir: Enter Device.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I'have broug'ht you a weapon Lady.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: Me, what to doe Sir.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Tis juſtice I preſent it to your feete, whoſe love Arm'd me to vindicate your honour.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: My honour?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: This is but the firſt of my valour in your cauſe; if you affect theſe monuments, I'le make you up an Armory: meane time receive my ſervice with this ſword; if hee provoake me to fight with him againe; I'le cut his hand off and bringe it with me, to preſent the next.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: Whoſe hand deare Servant?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Hee is not worth the naminge, alas; this does not deſerve your knowledge; only thinke what I dare doe, when your bright name is queſtioned: and I in time may merrit to bee call'd the darlinge of your Virgin thoughts.

sp.speaker: Siſt
sp.p: Pray ſtay; my name traduc'd? who was ſo impudent? doe me the grace to let me know on whome your valour has bin exercis'd.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Why upon the formall thinge, call'd Courtwell, I would call him Gentleman, but that I have baffled him; you neede noe other witneſſe then his ſword: Shee ſhuts the doore. With the fine holliday hilt.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: Looke you Sir I have made faſt the doore becauſe I meane before you goe, to have a ſatisfaction for the baſe Injury you have done me.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I done you Injury?

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p:
Not that I value Courtwell whome you would pretend has bin too ſaucy with my honour, but cauſe I ſcorne to owne a goodneſſe ſhould depend upon your ſword or vindication: I'le fight with thee my ſelfe in this
ſmale volume againſt your bulke in folio.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Excellent wench.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I was your champion, Lady.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: I had rather have no fame then have thee name it; thou fight for a Ladyes honour, and diſarme a Gentleman? thou fence before the Pageants & make roome for the porters, when like Elephants they carry once a yeare the Cyttie Caſtles: or goe a feaſtinge with the drum or ſchole boyes to the banke ſyde & ſave the beares a whippinge that day: come Sir I meane to have about with you.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: At what weapon?

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: This, and none other, Sir.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I'le rather bleede to death then lift a ſworde in my defence▪ whoſe inconſiderate brightneſſe may fright the roſes from your Cheekes, & leave the lyllyes to Lament the rude divorce: but were a man to dare me, and your enemie, my rage more nimble then the M • dian ſhaft ſhould flye into his boſome, and your eye change Anger into ſmiles, to ſee me fight and cut him into a ragged ſtaffe.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: I cannot hold no longer; you have got a ſtomack Sir with running, I'le try how you can eate a Sword.

sp.speaker: Dev
sp.p: Have you an ambuſh Lady; I'le cry out murther, tis two to one. Faire play!

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Let me but cut one legg off to marre his running.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Hold: let me ſpeake.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What canſt thou ſaie for thy baſeneſſe?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Some men love witt, and can without dishonour endure a Ieaſt; Why? doe you thinke I knew not you were heere & but obſerv'd to ſee my humour? I came to wayte upon you with your ſword.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: How came you by it? Confeſſe before this Lady.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Doeſt thinke her witt's ſo lymber to beleive I could compell it from thee, twas a trick, a meere conceipt of mirth, thou ſhalt have myne: Doeſt thinke I ſtand upon a ſword? I'le give thee a caſe of piſtolls, when wee come to London; and ſhoote mee when I love thee not: pox on it, thou apprehendeſt me well enough.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: But I am not ſatisfied, doe you loue this Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Hum;

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: You will reſolve Sir.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: As may become a ſtranger; I will not loſe thy friendſhipp for all woman kinde.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Hee dares, not owne you.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: I eaſily forgive him: I ſhould hate my ſelfe if I depended on his pitty.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Thou art a noble wench: ſhall wee leave of theſe Jiggs, and ſpeake our minds in earneſt by theſe twyn lipps, I loue thee extreamly.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: Sweare by your owne.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: They ſhall bee myne: Monſieur, for your pennance you ſhall a long & witneſſe.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: What I pray.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: The prieſt ſhall tell you, come, wee have both diſſembled, wee doe loue one an other.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: Tis not poſſible.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Vnleſſe you will denie me in the church. I have vowed to lye with you this night: Device, amble before, and finde the Parſon out; wee will bee frends, and thou ſhalt bee her Father.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: I muſt mayntayne my honour, or be beaten.

sp.speaker: Co.
sp.p: Com we'le have no more acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: Very pretty! I may deceave you yet for all your confidence.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: If the skye falle, wee'le have the darkes to ſupper. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Lady Sir Francis and Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: It was a ſtrange neglect, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I confeſſe it, and not deſerve to live for it, yet if you but knew my ſufferings.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Let her bee Judge.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: By no meanes Madame.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: You may truſt her knowledge.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: This is worſe then a whippinge now, theſe Ladyes have no mercy on a delinquent; I muſt ſtand to it; there is no tyrant to a chambermayde, made judge in ſuch a caſe; I'le give a limbe to bee quitt now; but if ſhee chuſe, I am a criple for this world.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Is it poſſible? A man and ſuch a beaſt?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Soe: I muſt to the ſhambles.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: What puniſhment can bee equall to the offence?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p:
Hee lookes with ſome compunction for his fault, troth, Madame, ſuch an other
night: and trye whether hee'le ſleepe againe.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Mercifull wench; if wee piece againe; it ſhall bee a good turne in thy way.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: My husband is reſolu'd this day for London. It is his humour, or elſe worſe, ſuſpition: there's noe pretence for him to ſtay behinde.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You have made ill uſe of your time Sir Francis; I know not how to helpe you; ſeauen yeares hence you may have ſuch an other opportunitie.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Watch if my husband come not this way, Dorothy, well Sir, though your tranſgreſsion deſerve no pardon, yet I am charitable upon condition.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Any thinge, Madame: this ſhewes excellent in you. No pennance ſhall diſpleaſe, ſo you abſolue me. Bid me to clyme ſome rocke or piramide, upon whoſe narrow ſpeare you have advanc'd my peace, and I will reach it, or elſe fall loſt to the world in my contempt.

sp.speaker: Lad
sp.p: You ſpeake gloriouſly, the condition that aſſures your pardon, is only this, that you conclude, here, all your looſe deſires, with a reſolve never to proſecute or hope to enjoye me:

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Call you this charitie, let me rather looſe your pardon, then ever bee thus Divorc'd: binde me never to ſee you, (and yet that were cruelty) then, charme me to forget that I am man, or have a heart, and you a beautie which your abſence can as well make nothinge, as divide from my adoreing
It is not cure but killing to preſcribe I never muſt enioye you, if you have reſolu'd death upon me, let it bee when wee like lovers have embrac'd.

sp.speaker: Lad
sp.p: It is not poſsible.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: nothing in loue can bee impoſſible to willing mynds. I'le tell you, Madame, Sure the devill has forſworne the fleſh, there may bee a plott, I have it. An excellent rare Dovice, if you but favour it: your husband is immediately for London I muſt in modeſty ride with him; you are left behinde.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: How can that proffit you?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: What a deale of ſubmiſſion theſe fooliſh men trouble us women with, that are more forward to bee frends againe, then they?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I will counterfeit a fall.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: A fall?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I, from my horſe, obſerve me then.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My confederate I hope by this time is at the gate enquiringe for Sir Richard very formally from the old Knight his Maſter & good Lady: the follow has witt to mannage it.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My F • o man ſhall pretend himſelfe the ſurgeon to attend me; I'ſt not rare? ſtand but to it fate in this and if I faile I will ſit downe a convert and renownce all wanton hope hereafter. Deereſt Madame if you did meane this honour to me before let not your louinge thoughts freeze in a minute; my genius is a prophet.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Sir Richard, Madame, is cominge this way.

sp.speaker: Fran
sp.p: Shall I hope againe

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: I will not ſay you ſhall diſpayre.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: You bleſſe me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My buſineſſe is on foote, your Jewell Madame will credit much the cauſe.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Wee will with draw; and let me know how you, have caſt the plott. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Sir Richard (openinge a letter) & Footman.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: From thy Maſter? his name?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Sir William Litleland.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I doe not know him.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: His name is well known in Lincolneſhire neere the Fenns; there were of his family Ancient Gentlemen before the conqueſt, ſome ſay, ever ſince the flood,

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Little Land?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: But hee has now more land then 3. of the beſt of the ſheere, thank the dutch men that have drunke up al the water.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: They water—drinkers?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Why not, as well as eate dry land? they are lyn'd with butter; Sir; they feare noe dropſies.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.

p.hi:
Shee has bin abſent theſe two yeares, the occaſion her diſlike and diſaffection to a Gentleman whome I confeſſe, I did ſeverely urge her to marry, if ſhee have liv'd with you, as my late intelligence informs me in the nature of a Servant, which is be •• ath my wiſh and her cōdition, I hope upon this knowledge, you will with conſider of her qualittie ſhee beinge my
only child and heyre to my fortunes, uſe her like a Gentlewoman: and though my peares have made me unfitt for trauell I doe Intend upon the returne of my daughter, whome I ſhall receive as a new bleſſinge from you, to expreſſe my ſelfe for your favour

closer.signed: Your trew Frend and Servant WILLIAM LITTELAND.

sp.p: My maid Dorothy A knights daughter & heire? doe you know your younge Miſtriſſe?

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: I ſhall bee happie to ſee her, with a Letter and token from her Lady Mother.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I pray truſt me to deliver it.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: I, With all my heart, Sir; you may command.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: T • omas, pray entertaine this Footman in the buttery: let him drinke & refreſh him ſelfe and ſet the cold chine of beefe before him hee has runn hard.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: That will ſtay his ſtomack indeede; but claret is his only binder.

sp.speaker: Foot.
sp.p: Sack while you liue after a heate, Sir.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Peaſe you, I'le ſhew you the way to be drunke. Exit with Footman.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: To my lovinge daughter? may not this bee a trick? Enter Vnderwitt.
By your favour Madame; Captaine, gather you the ſence of that Letter, while I peruſe this, you know Miſtris Dor • thy?

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p:
I have had a greate deſire to know her,
I confeſſe, but ſhee is ſtill like the bottom of the mapp, Terra incognita, I have ben a long time hoveringe about the Magellan ſtraytes but have made no new diſcoveryes.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Ha! This is no counterfeit; I dare truſt my owne Judgment; tis a very rich one I am confirm'd, and I will ſeale them up againe. My Ladyes Woman Sir William Littelands daughter and heyre? what ſay you now of Miſtreſſe Dorothy?

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: A great deale better then I did, and yet I have loud her this halfe yeare in a kinde of way, of my conſcence, why may not I marry her?

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: This Jewell was ſent by her Mother to her.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Deare Vncle conceale it till I have talke with her, oh for ſome witchcraft to make all ſure.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I like this well: ſhee's here.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: I vow, Miſtreſſe Dorothy; if I were immodeſt, it was the meere impudence of my ſack, and not my owne diſpoſition but if you pleaſe to accept my loue now by the way of marriage I'le make you ſatisfaction, like a Gentleman in the point of honour.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: your birth and eſtate is to high and unequall for me, Sir.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: What care I for portion or a face, ſhee that has good eyes, has good—Give me vertue.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You are pleas'd to make your mirth of me.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: By this ruby nay; you ſhall weare it in the broad eye of the world; doeſt thinke I jeſt?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Sir Richard:—

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: If hee were ten Sir Richards, I am out of my wardſhip

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: How hee flutters in the lyme-buſh: it takes rarely. Aſide.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: What a neceſſary thinge were a houſhold chapline? Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: So; ſo; the wench inclynes, I will haſten my jornie that I may appeare with more excuſe, when they are married in my abſence. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Master Courtwell, Sister and Device.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Come wee are faſt enough, and now I have thee, I'le tell the all the fault I finde, thou haſt a little two much wit, to bee a wife: it could not bee too nimble for a Miſtreſſe. There is a part of your pennance ſtill behind Device; you would pretend to bee a poet, I'le not diſgrace the name to call thee one, but let me have times againſt wee goe to bed, Two Anagrames that weigh an ownce with coment, and after that, in verſe your affidavitt that you doe wiſh us joye, and I'le diſcharge you.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Tis time I were at ſtudy then.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p:
About them, your double congie, and depart with ſilence: now prithee tell me who reported I had wrong'd a Lady? Was it
not thy revenge to make me Angry?

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: It was indeed Now tell me; why at the firſt approach ſeem'd you ſo modeſt? you have confidence to ſpare, now.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Troth I came not with any wooinge purpoſe: only to pleaſe my Vnkle, and try thy witt and that converted me. Enter Tho.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Did you ſee my Maſter Captaine Vnderwit?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Yes he's talkinge with a prieſt and Miſtreſſe Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: Her Fathers Footeman is heere, ſhee is a Knights daughter and heyre, but ſhee doth not know it.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: I thinke ſoe?

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Where's my Vnkle?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: A myle on his way to London, by this time with Sir Richard, I longe to ſee my Maſter. Exit.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Wee ſhall want Companie to dance.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: My Siſter.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: If you pleaſe Madame, you may call me, Brother, wee have ben at, I Iohn take thee Eliſabeth, a poſſett and foure naked thighes in a bed to night, wee'le bid faire earneſt for a boy too.

sp.speaker: Siſt.
sp.p: Tis even ſo Madame; the Prieſt has done it

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Nay then all joyes attend you; if this had bin knowen, it might have, ſtay'd Sir Richard, and your Vnkle one day more.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Roome for an other couple.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: In hell, my Maſter is maried.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: My husband left ſome letters, and a token was ſent you Miſtris Dorothy, you did Ill to obſcure your ſelfe ſo much, you ſhall not want hereafter all reſpects that may become you.

sp.speaker: D • r
sp.p: Madame I know not what you meane.

sp.speaker: Cap.
sp.p: Shee will not take it upon her, yet.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: There is the ſport Enter Device.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Oh Madame, newes; Ill newes; an Accident which will blaſt all your mirth, Sir Francis;—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: What of him.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Has broake;—

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: His neck?

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: You gueſſe very neere it, tis but, his ſhoulder has ſav'd that Joynt; a fall from his horſe they ſaye hath much endangerd him.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: My Vnckle hurt? Exit.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Hee has kept his word; now if hee counterfeyte handſomely.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Monſieur Device, I muſt entreat a courteſie: you have wit and I will have a Maſque to entertaine my new Father in Law Sir William Littleland; Miſtris Dorothy now my wife is his only daughter & heyre

sp.speaker: D • r.
sp.p: Who has gull'd you thus? I am no Knights daughter.

sp.speaker: Dev.
sp.p: Give you Joy Captaine

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Shee is ſtill loath to confeſſe it.

div.stage: Enter Sir Francis; Master Courtwell, Lady, Sister, Sackbury.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: If you loue charitie; a bone ſetter.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Hee counterfeites rarely, where is Sir Richard.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Hee rid before, but I ſent my Footeman, to tell him my misfortune; oh; Madame.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: This is better then the tooth atch; he carries it excellently.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Aske me no torturinge queſtions, I deſire Madame a little conference with you, I'le thanke the reſt if they will with draw.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Lett's leaue him.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Wee'le to my chamber, Captaine.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: You have a minde to examine the buſineſſe privatly.

sp.speaker: Vnd
sp.p: No, good Captaine you may bee preſent, come; Thomas, thou ſhalt bee wittneſſe too. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: They are gone, you faine moſt Artificially, let me embrace you.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Oh take heede.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: What's the matter.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Tis noe diſſembling, Madame; I have had a fall indeede: a dreadfull fall, I feele it, I thinke my horſe ſawe the devill in ſome hedge, ere I had rid three furlongs: gaue a ſtart, pitch'd me off his back like a barre and broake a flynt with my ſhoulder, I thinke; which ſtrooke fire too there was ſomethinge like it in my eyes; I am puniſhed.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: But is this ſerious, are you hurt indeede?

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
Hurt? I have broake my ſhoulder, feelingly, and I am of opinion when I doe enjoy you, Madame, I ſhall breake my neck: that will bee the next; I'le take this for a
warninge and will leaue of in time.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: It makes me tremble.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I will bee honeſt now, and ſo forgive me, is not the ſurgeon come yet?

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: Heaven hath cur'd us both.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: I am not cur'd yet, oh for the bone ſetter, if ever I counterfeit againe.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: There is a bleſsing falne upon my bloud: your only thoughts charme had power to make my thoughts wicked, and your converſion diſenchants me: may both our liues be ſuch as heaven may not greeve, to have ſhewed this bountie.

div.stage: Enter Courtwell and the rest with Sir Richard.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Sir Richard; Madame:

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: You may enter now, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: I doe not like this Stratagem, Sir Francis muſt not heere practice his court tricks, I will not truſt my wifes ſurgery:
Hee's come; Sir Francis is led out.
How is it noble Sir Francis; beſt with draw, I'le ſee him dreſt my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Madame and Gentleman; Miſtriſſe D • rothy will not acknowledge ſhe is a Knights daughter ſhe ſweares ſhe knowes no Littleland.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Till it appeare to whome, this • emm was meant, deafe Madame, bee you treaſurer, I confeſſe I have wealth enough in ſuch a noble husband.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: It ſhall belonge to thee; be honeſt Dorothy, and uſe him well.

sp.speaker: D • r.
Sack.
sp.p: Where is this Foo •• man you talke of?

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: He p • etended letters to carry two myles off to a Kinſmans of his Maſters and returne preſently: hee drunke 3. or 4. beere glaſſes of Sack and hee rune away ſo lightly.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: His reward ſhall overtake him.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Will you have her; ſhee'le doe you ſervice, Captaine at a low Country leager or thou Thomas I le give thee a coppihold.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: You have one life to come in that leaſe yet, I thanke you I am free, and that is Inheritance. For ought I know ſhee may ſerve us both.

sp.speaker: Sack.
sp.p: Come you may perſuade her to take it upon her for your creditt, the gullery is yet with in theſe walls let your ſhames goe noe further, the wench may prove right; ſhee may.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: What newes from Sir Francis.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Wife I hartily aske thy forgiveneſſe: I had jealous thoughts, but all is right againe.

sp.speaker: Lad.
sp.p: I will deſerve your confidence.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: No greate danger, his blade bone diſlocated: the man has put every thinge in his right place

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Doe you heare Sir Richard, wee are married.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Tis well done t'is to my mynd, ſend you Joy;

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: Come hither Dorothy.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: My Mother dyed, I have it by tradition, ſoe, as ſoone as I was borne my Father but no Knight, is now in the Indies a poore Marchant that broake for 20000.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: The ſhips may come home, ha;

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: You had beſt uſe me well now wee are married, I will bee ſworne you forc'd me to the church and thriſe compeld me there to ſaid, I Dorothy—The Parſons oath and mine, for ought I know may make it halfe a rape.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: There is no remedy wee can proue no conſpiracy; and becauſe I have bin gull'd my ſelfe, gett her with childe; my Doe is barren, at birth of hir firſt baby I'le give thee a hundred peeces.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: That's ſomewhat yet: when charge coms on, thy hand, a wife can bee but a wife: it ſhall coſt me 500. but I'le make thee a Laay in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: How is it Sir Francis.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: My Surgeon ſayes no danger: when you pleaſe I may venture Sir to London.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Noe haſt now.

sp.speaker: Court.
sp.p: Not to night, Sir, wee muſt have revells, and you ſalute my bride.

sp.speaker: Vnd.
sp.p: And myne.

sp.speaker: Tho.
sp.p: A Knights daughter and heyre.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p:
May all Joyes thriue upon your Ioues; then you are cozen'd of your Miſtreſſe Monſieur, but your nephew knowes
I have met with my match if not put to the worſt.

sp.speaker: Sir Rich.
sp.p: Come wee looſe time.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Preſerve your Marriage faith: a full increaſe of what you wiſh confirme your happineſſe.

div.p: THE VARIETIE, A COMOEDY, Lately preſented by His Majeſties Servants at the Black-Friers.
LONDON, Printed for Humphrey Moſeley, and are to be ſold at his Shop at the Princes Armes in St. Pauls Churchyard. 1649.

list.item: SIr William, A Sutor to the Lady Beaufield.
Maſter Newman, A Sutor to Miſtris Lucy.
Formall, Gentleman-uſher to the Lady Beaufield.

div.head: Act I. Scaene I.
div.stage: Enter Sir William (at one doore:) Mr Manly (at the other.)

sp.speaker: Sr. Wil.
sp.p: I Ack Manly, well met.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Noble Sir William the humbleſt of your ſervants.

sp.speaker: Sr. Wil.
sp.p: Come, thou ſhalt along with me.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Whither?

sp.speaker: Sr. Wil.
sp.p: To ſee my Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: May you thrive in your courtſhip to her: at this time I am engag'd to other buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Can any thing concerne a Gentleman equall with a handſome Lady?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Yes, the receiving of money is more conſiderable with me at this time, than all the women in the world. But who is your Miſtris Knight?

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p:
I dare tell thee, Madam Beaufield, the
Lady of ſpirit, and entertainment, the only Magnetick widdow i'th Town.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: They talk her a wit, and a moſt ſuperſtitious obſerver of perſons, and their garbes; I never had the happineſs to kiſs her hand, or be known to her, but I converſe with ſome who are very high and loud in her character; another time Enter Jeere Major, and Minor. Ile wait upon you. Who are theſe?

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: In what grott haſt thou ſpent thy time, that thou art ignorant of theſe people? Theſe two are held the wits; That is the remarkable Jeerer of the Town, and 'has purchas'd to himſelf the title of a Jeere Major.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why, Is there a Regiment of Jeerers?

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: You ſhall pardon me, there are ſets of them, as there are of Fidlers; there is firſt a ſet of Court Jeerers, ſpruce half-witted men, confident, and fierce in their opinions; theſe are men that make themſelves muſick, and their cloths make roome for their wic; and go before in all companies: Then there is the town Jeerers, like Hoboyes or Waites of the City, that think they are wiſe when they are loud, and make a noiſe when they come to Plaies, to diſtract the next mans underſtanding. There are Jeerers at time of the yeer that go down into the Countrey, and infect Wakes, and Faires, and the Sizes, with their impudence, with which they ſave charges, and are never without the name of a great Lord, to whom they are coſin Germane.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
But what has he deſerved to be called 〈◊〉
Jeere Major, and to beare ſuch a title? I have ſeen the Rooke.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: An excellent ill nature has preferd him to opinion: the other has merited but the name of a Jeere minor; yet they can ſee me pleaſant in their reproaches, and laugh in their own defence, which many times keeps off the cudgell.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay, Jeering is a bleſſing that every man may have if he give his mind to it: but wit (if I remember what I was taught) happens not to one amongſt five hundred on 'em. But I forget my affaire.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: Shall's meet and be merry this Evening.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Theres no muſick in me without my ſinging birds about me, then I am a Lord, and when I put on my habit of Leiſter, I am his own excellence.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: Doſt thou preſerve that him or ſtill?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I may chance by the falſe light of the Evening march to thy Lodging.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: Doſt know where tis? I am remov'd. (whiſper.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: So, no diſcoveries what Prince I am.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: A match: that ſhape will beget us ſome mirch.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Your moſt humble ſervant. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: My Miſtris is ſomewhat melancholy, if he come in that phantaſticall habit, we ſhall have rare ſport beyond his expectation, to have the Ladies laugh at him. Exit.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: This is very fine wit yſaith, and ſoone learnd I thinke; a little more on't ſweet Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Jeer.
sp.p:
Suppoſe you were foxd laſt night; thus I come to you, and accoſt; Save you Sir; you muſt
know I muſt laugh all the while; how fare you Sir? Do not ſome fumigations remaine, ſome vapours not diſſipated, a kind of Vertigo, a weakning of the Nerves, or ſo? Ha, ha, ha, what thinks your Worſhip of milke now, thin broth, or a Julip of pitifull Six for a penance to ſettle you, or a haire of the ſame whelp? Ha, ha, ha, there's wit for you.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: There's no harme in the world in it, nor no exceptions if you laugh in the right place.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Now imagine you met an honourable Gentleman that had got a hurt in the groine; thus I invade you; but the laugh muſt hold me too.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: By any meanes, I cannot chooſe but laugh my ſelf.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: There is no ſafe jeering without it.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Sir, you have been at puſh of pike and received a hurt, upon ſome unſlaught in ſome female ſervice, Ha, ha, ha; your breath is Aromatick ſince you kiſs'd your Miſtris, and your water out-ſmells the violet, ha, ha, ha; by the powerfull—yclipped Turpentine, tis true; what pitty tis you went without a charme, or had no acquaintance with a Laplander, to make you Venus-ſhot-free? Ha, ha, ha; and how many french tenniſtalls have you in your flanke now? ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: You ſate up at play all night, and loſt your money; another now.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Not I a penny, I ſent a buffe Gentleman that lookt big upon me, after an ill hand, twenty peeces upon halfe a dozen oaths.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p:
A good pawne, keep his oaths, if he do not pay your money, take the forfeit, and if he be
a Gameſter he'll be undone for want of ſwearing.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Suppoſe it loſt?

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Me thinks Cavallier you looke pale ſince you came from the charnelhouſe, did the bones affright you? you are a moſt religious Gentleman when you are at dice, and do ſo pray for 3 fives 3 foures at in and in: with what devotion you look on the ſeven of Spades and eight of Diamonds at cribbiſh? ha, ha; how zealouly you invoke the Saints to fit you with cards at picket, or lebet.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I invoke the Saints?

sp.speaker: 1 Jer.
sp.p: I ſpeake to the catholicke gameſter, that underſtands all games.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: By the way though, doe you think there are any gameſters in heaven?

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: It is to be feared, they may loſe ſo much upon earth, they will hardly purchaſe a place there, or if any get thither, (which muſt be excellent throwing) he would be more call'd upon, and perhaps puld downe agen, upon every diſpute at play to be Groome porter.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: How like you theſe?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: You ſhall both with me to my Miſtris, and help to Jeere my rivalls.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Your Miſtris?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I Miſtris Luoy, Lady Beaufeilds daughter, my Landlady Miſtris Ʋoluble has commended me to her, and I hope to carry her, if one Gentl. that ſhe loves better do not get her away?

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: Wee'l jeere him to death.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
That were an excellent way, I thinke there is no ſtatute againſt that, I care not what becomes on him, he put bitter jeſts upon me tother
day before the Ladies, and I making uſe of your wit Gentlemen, he told me to my face, that I talk'd nothing but clinches; as I am a Gentleman he did.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Oh barbarous!

sp.speaker: 1 Jer.
sp.p: You ſhall wound him with his owne weapon, and by a direction we can give you, you ſhall ſo jeere him, that he ſhall offer boote to change underſtandings with you.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Wee'l make him ſo ridiculous, he ſhal laugh at himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: That will be rare; I have ſent for my Mother to towne to be acquainted with Ladies, and learn dreſſing; my Landlady, hath promiſed to commend a Gentlewoman to waite upon her, and teach her the art of painting, and all the poſtures of a great woman; I do meane ſhe ſhall marry ſome Knight or other, and be Ladified.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: It wil be neceſſary.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Though I ſay it, the woman is flexible, and has been in her daies—My Father might have been a Knight, and he had not been an Aſſe, and lov'd his mony; but we loſe time, let's to my Miſtres Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Both
sp.p: We attend ſir. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: The ſame day, a Dolphin taken in a net at Woolidge, and ten live Pilchards in a Salmons belly—ſtrange things! the 13. of July, the Caramountaine kittend in the Tower: an Eeleſhip ſpring a leak ſhooting the Bridge,—heere are prodigious things. Enter Newman.
Mr. Newman.

sp.speaker: New
sp.p: Mr. Uſher, how does your Lady?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: She is in health.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: And Miſtris Lucy?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Both in the Garden. Sir you have good intelligence, what newes abroad? a touch to your ſervant.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Alas you are acquainted with the ſtate myſteries.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Troth Sir, I know little, or if I did, I would be loath to ſpeake it, but to a friend, the times are dangerous.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Y'are right Mr. Formall, but be not nice, I know you are furniſh'd with newes, as well as ſome that give penſions, though 'twere to a Captaine in theſe warlike-times, to have it made for 'em; you being a quotidian ambler upon impertinent viſits, muſt needs gleane the ſecrets of the court and ſtate.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Sir I dare truſt you with any thing, but pray do not ſpeak on't; there is a great man in the world—

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Think you ſo?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: That—

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What has he done?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You ſhall excuſe me; but—

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: VVhat his name?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You ſhall excuſe me for that too; a word to the wiſe; you can gueſſe what I meane, and let that paſſe; and now we talke of ſtate affaires, there is a packet come out of the North, and abox—in your eare ſir.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What is ſaid to be in that packet?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Ther's the buſineſſe, but that no body knowes.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Is't poſſible?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Tak't upon my word; you are a friend, I heare further at Mr. Secretaries, but you muſt ſay nothing of it, you undoe me if you doe, the King goes to Hampton Court next weeke, but how long he ſtayes is uncertaine. Sir, you ſee I put my ſelfe into your hands.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: But is this done like a wiſeman to reveale theſe myſteries, to truſt theſe ſecrets to one you have not known above 7 Yeare, if I ſhould inform what will become of you, and your eſtate? oh you muſt be cautious, though for my part—

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Oh Sir! I know to whom I ſpeak, and will tell you more, for I dare truſt you with my ſoule; they ſay the Northerne progreſſe holds this yeare, and that the Elke is dead in the new great parke

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I hope not.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Tis as I tell you, by the fall of a tree, doe not you remember a tempeſt foure nights agoe? then 'twas, bluſtring times Mr. Newman.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: That makes Ʋan Trumpe ſo troubled with the winde colicke, but now the Hollanders, as they report, have many Engineers and Mathematitians ſet a work, how to keep and vent it at their pleaſure, and ſo to ſerve in Navigation for their ſhips, that there may be ventus liber, as well as ventus clauſus, anſwerable to the two Seas.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Ha, ha! that's newes indeed, alas mine is but domeſtick, but what do you heare of London Bridge? it is whiſper'd by ſome it will, and ſome againe point blank ſay it will not be repaired; but make not me the Authour.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p:
And I do heare the Camells decay at
Tiballs: but pray no more of it from me.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You ſhall not doubt me Sir, you do not heare of the Dolphin—

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Of France?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Taken as Woolidge in a net.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Of Italian cutworke.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: The newes is not common of the Pilchards, the Catamountaine, nor the Eeleſhip?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Not a word.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You ſhall heare more; I am your ſervant. Here is Miſtris Lucy Sir, and Miſtris Ʋoluble.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: I confeſſe he has no overcharge of wit, that will be your happineſſe, he has a good eſtate, and you may live with more delight than a court Lady, he is a handſome man too, I am bound to give you my adviſe, for your mothers ſake, whoſe ſervant I am by many obligations, ſhe has been my cuſtomer for face-water, and pomatum theſe many yeares.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: But if you be ſo skilfull, as you are profeſt, and read in the ſecrets of nature, you can tell by your art where I ſhall fixe my affection, doe not you know Mr. Newman.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: I never ſee the Gentleman, but I am not ignorant that he matches in the Vanne, and leades the file of your amorous ſervants, but—

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: But what?

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: If you love your ſelfe.—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He is a well-bred Gentleman, and one deſerves my good opinion, hee's here.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They obſerve me— Exit Form:
I kiſſe your hand faire Miſtris Lucy: whats ſhe that lookes ſo like one of the Sibills?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Is this the Gentleman you declare ſo civill, and well-bred, Lady? If I have any skill take heed on him, he has an unlucky countenance.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: This Gypſey will but cozen you.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: She is excellent cunning, and has foretold ſtr ange things, beleeve it.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: If my Miſtris have an opinion of her Art, ſhe may do me a diſpleaſure; I have heard much talk of this woman, ſome ſay ſhe is a Witch too, and weares the Devill in her thumbe Ring, I would not anger one of her Familiars. Take no offence Miſtris at the rudeneſſe of my Language, this Lady ſhall give a very faire pawne, the word of a Gentlewoman, that I ſhall be of good behaviour, if you pleaſe not to interpret me too haſtily.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: There is ſome texs in your forehead Sir that wants a comment, but Ile not ſo much ſtudy your ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Nay, thou ſhalt not be diſpleaſed with him.

div.stage: Enter Lady Beaufield, and Sir William.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Alas, I am not angry; heres my Lady and Sir William.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You are Maſter of an excellent language Sir.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: You honour me too much, it is becauſe you are the excellent Subject Madam, and being the perfection of your Sexe, an argument to create Eloquence in every tongue.

sp.speaker: Beau
sp.p: Then I muſt think you flatter; theſe praiſes are miſplac'd. I ſhall ſuſpect you love me not, or are not wiſe.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: Why Madam?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: You take ſuch paines, and make a pilgrimage to thats within your reach; I muſt confeſs I like Diſcourſe, but think not all my ſoule plac'd in my eare; although I love a Lute well, it follows not I ſhould dote upon a Cimball.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: A Cimball?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: And dance as I were ſtong with a Tarantula, when you are at it, roſting of a Galliard? You overdo this inſtrument, give me your courtſhip in a phraſe is fit to own and underſtand.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: Your pardon Madam; I affect not bold and over-rack'd Hyperboles, although I might inſiſt upon the wealth and fulneſs of your merits, to which, all praiſe, that can flow from me, is Juſtice, ſuch command you have upon your humble Servant, I rather wiſh my tongue a forfeit to perpetuall ſilence, then with one harſh ſound offend your eare; you'l give me leave I hope to ſay I love you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: This is Engliſh Sir, and ſome do call it ſence; 'tis faire, and fit, when any Lady's private with her Servant; 'tis what I learn'd a child, I have not yet outgrown the knowledge.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Did you love ſo young?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p:
I underſtand the meaning of your language, 'tis not perplext, and you may love me too, and tell me ſo, and I may underſtand you; what need compartments here, freeſes, and words of Architecture, that will make things hard to the underſtanding? As you could not build a ſence in love without 'em? Yet I bar not the freedom of Diſcourſe, and uſe of Metaphors: And you may praiſe us too in Verſe, or Proſe, to ſhew the exaltation of your wit in company, but 'tis the worſt
diſcourſe when we are private.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: If I had confidence ſhe would direct me—action I beleeve when opportunity Invites—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: To what good Knight? be not miſtaken, I commend courtſhip in words, that are made round like pills fit to be ſwallowed, and not ragged bullets.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: 'Tis a ſtrange Lady, I know not how to take her.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: My Lady? Madam—

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Art thou come?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Is it your Ladiſhips pleaſure I ſhall read to day?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: By any meanes, the Ladies will not faile, we ſhould forget our Academy: Sir William we muſt entreat your patience, and Maſter Newman. Vol. whiſpers to Sr Wil.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Madam, the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Say I wait upon 'em.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Ile take my opportunity.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: You will engage him to credulity, and prepare ſome mirth.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Mounſier Galliard the Dancer attends Madam.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: He muſt give way to another exerciſe; Sir William you ſhall do us a favour if you pleaſe to entertaine a little time with him in the next Chamber, our Lecture will not be long, and ſweet Mr Newman the French-man will delight you with his diſcourſes, he has a tongue as confident as his feet, if you can but humour him.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: You ſhall command us Madam.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: That Done wee'l joine ſocieties and mirth. Come Mrs Voluble.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I hope you will excuſe my imperfections. Exeunt.

div.head: Act II. Scaene I.
div.stage: Table and ſix Chaires ſet out. Enter Lady Beaufield, Lucy, and other Ladies, Miſtris Voluble.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p:
IT is an infinite favour, (moſt excellent Ladies) and muſt needs ſpeak the ſweetneſs of your nature and diſpoſitions, that y'are pleas'd to hear me, ſo weak and unworthy of the Chaire, rather deſerving to be in the number of Diſciples, than a profeſſor in any of the female ſciences; but as your vertues are more exemplary, in this honour to me, the humbleſt of your Servants, it will become me, in the gratitude to ſo noble a bounty, not to waſte time, but ſuccinctly to deliver, what I could not finiſh without treſpaſſe on your patience; at my laſt reading I did conclude with old Ladies, that will cozen Nature, and Time, and abuſe the men they love beſt; to theſe I only add, it is not Mercury to change their skins like Snakes, but they muſt fill up wrinckles as well as hide gray haires: your red leather is for Countrey Wenches, your white waſh, or Spaniſh Fucus is the beſt, but a tire woman,
or coverer of time or nakedneſs muſt be kept in penſion: ſor it is now faſhionable to buy one of her apprencice Girles out of her time, as Lords and Gentlemen do Barbers boyes. Amongſt other ornaments, Ribbands challenge no meane place, the variety, and blaſon of theſe, I have elſewhere examined. For your fineſt Laces, the Angel in Cheape, but they muſt be dearer then others, becauſe they come in Coaches, for pride or ſtatelineſs in any thing adds charges. Touching Gloves, might I adviſe, I would have a few ſelected Ladies, to procure ſome ingenious Gentleman at a reaſonable penſion to lye Lerger for them at Rome for Frangepane Gloves, and ſuch other correſpondent things as may be of moment and great conſequence to your Ladyſhips: But then I muſt advertiſe, and moſt ſeriouſly, that he may be a man of parts, and ſomewhat ſmelling toward the Roman Waſh, that he may give you intelligence of that State, and humours of the Gardinals, or thoſe that pretend to it, be they little or great, for this concernes the ſtate Ladies here: For your ſwarfie Mountebanke Italian, he utters ſophiſticated Holborne Gloves for Frangepane, Eſſe •
Cheeſe for Parmeſan, rotten poſt for ſweet powder, pickled white Leather for Muſhromes, and cozens more with his broken Engliſh, then the wits can get honeſily with their beſt language.

sp.speaker: 1 Lady
sp.p: The Merchant of Italian Saulſages, A meet Quack.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p:
But then I would adviſe your Ladiſhips to have another Gentleman ſent into Spaine for perfumes, pocket Fannes, orange flower water, Orange flower butter beauty, Aqua de Chedrey,
and many provocatives, as Contra yerua, and Joco lata.

sp.speaker: 2 Lady
sp.p: It is a very learned Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: For Holland, 'tis too deare in Spaine, therefore for a conſcionable cozenage over and above, here are honeſt Dutchmen will ſerve you moſt faithfully. For Jewels, you may buy them at what rates you pleaſe, they add luſtre to a Lady, and you may ſell them at a fift or ſift part, which is very well for a great Madam, if you would put them off at the beſt rate, you muſt get ſome Doctor of Phiſick, or broking Apocriphall Captain, to ſhew them (as if there were fornication in it) behind the doore, hanging or curtaine, which makes his fingers like Jewellers cardes to ſet rings on, for there are bawdes for rings and Jewels, as well as for other commodities.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: What do you think of this caution Madam?

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: For your Linnen, it muſt be fine, and freſh every day, therein conſiſts humane delight. For linnen breeches, though ſome think them cleanly, in my opinion they imitate a Dutch Stove too much. For Aprons, plaine Holland is moſt becomming, ſtarch'd Lawne was in Queen Elizabeths time, and will not endure rumpling, every thing muſt be ſquar'd by uſe and elegance; but for your white Shoes, rich Roſes, light-coloured ſilk Stockings, and ſuch variety below ſtaires, they are great Inducers, as a learned man told me, (I will not ſay a Divine) for Love, moſt excellent Ladies, doth ſometimes aſcend, as well as deſcend.

But ſtill remember Ladies, that your Fanne be ſo little, as not to loſe the leaſt ſmirke, or grace
of your countenance for it, for then being ſo ſmall, when you put it to your face, ſome Courtiers may take it for a black patch. Then for your oaths, I proteſt is out of faſhion, I profeſſe for a Juſtice of Peaces Wiſe, I vow too maſculine, yfaith for a Chambermaid, Introth for a Landerer, As you hope to live, too like a Prayer; Never ſtir, would diſadvantage a Lady many waies, beſides viſits; For the active wenches of the time, May they be damn'd eternally, and loſe all their deſigns if it be not ſo; Upon my honour ſounds well, which in a great Lady can never be forfeited if ſhe be in love, for great women have their privilege of Nobility, and can never be forſworn like the Common people.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Is Perjury in women no breach of Laws?

sp.speaker: 4 Lady.
sp.p: You have the Doctors opinion.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: One touch, if you grow old, which I omitted formerly, When time, which is the moath of beauty, creeps upon you, you muſt be ſure to have ſo many leaves and curtaines before your windows, that you may ſhew your ſelves at more varions lights than the moſt cozening Mercer his faded and deceitfull Wares, for the youth of your white Satin will be then but pearle colour at the beſt, it may be but aſh-colour, and therefore refuſe no advantage to give it gloſs, according to the concluſion of a moderne Poet, which at this preſent ſhall be mine.

q.l: Wiſe Ladies muſt refuſe no Art
For age will ſnow upon their heart:

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p:
You have done us a great honour, and Ladies you ſhall not deny me this favour to taſte of a ſmall banquet that waites upon you in the
next roome, ſhall I ſhew the way. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Sir William, Mr. Newman, Monſieur Galliard.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me be content to have de litell patience, and be my trot, me tell you, vat me have ſeene a to day, de fine ſport in devarle, me come into de great man to day, me make de reverence Alamode, come ill faut, and he make me de eſtrange a Sir reverence de tird time, dat ever you ſaw.

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: That was not civill.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Oh Monſieur, every man has not the activity of your feet.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: By my fat, 'tis very eſtrange a ding, dat dey will ſuffer a des men to be neere a de King, a de Queene, de Prince, or de Princeſſe, dey vil marra de underſtanding very muſh.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Why Mounſieur that lyes at the other end.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar you ſhall excuſe a me, for de Courtier Alamode, dere de vit lie in de foot, begar dere is nobodie can be viſeman, dat does no make a de moſt excellent reverence, dat is moſt certaine, dat is the beſt ting in de hole varle.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I am cleare of his opinion.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: But do you think Caeſar Sir, or moſt of the Emperors or worthies of the world, ſtudied the liberall ſcience of the foot, or puiſſant toe?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: No, but begar dat make dem dye all unfortunate, for if dey had tinke of noting but de reverence, dey might ha live a great a while.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Excellent well argued, and very cleare in my underſtanding.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p:
I confeſſe the wiſedome of it Sir, but
for the wit do you thinke that lyes there?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Dat be de beſt vit can be poſſible, for your vit, vat is your vit? your vit is to breake a de jeaſt, vel, looke you now a me, me vil breake a de jeaſt, dat is like dat a me lor, dat is like dat of de Knight, dat is like dat of de Ientilman, ha, ha, ha! dere is now one, two, tre very good jeaſts, by my trot dey are ſo very good jeaſt, dat make a me ſicke wide laugh, and begar me vil make a de page, de lacquey, & all de foole in de court, breake a des very good jeaſt, very quickly, dat is a noting.

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: To any purpoſe?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What doe you thinke of the grave Aldermen? they are wiſe, and yet they doe not trouble themſelves much about legs.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Be my trot, me ſpeake a to de King, and to de Queene, to give me a patten, dat none ſhall teach a de Aldermen to make a de reverence but my ſelfe, and me vil undertake dat vid in one 12 a mont, but den dey muſt doe nothing elſe, dey ſhall make a de reverence, vid de Aldermen in de paris, and dance a Coran, a Cereban, a Mountague, and dat vil be very brave.

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: VVhat faculties ſome men have?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: But what ſhall buſineſſe do in the meane time Mounſieur?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Is not dis very great a buſineſſe? may begar, me vil undertake to de King and to de Queen to make a my Lor Mayre de Sheriff and de Aldermen very fine a mask.

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: And to write it Mounſieur?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Aw, de write? dat is noting alamode, your ſpeeſh two, tre, yard long, pſhaw? give a me de quick a ſpirit, de fancie, de brave ſcene,
de varietie of de Antimaſque, de nimble a foot, no matre de ſence, begar it vole be de braveting in de chriſtian varle.

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: There is no queſtion to be made.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: And be my trot if me have a noder patten for de counſell learned in the law, for to teach dem de reverence, dat vil be very great varke, but my diligence, and skill in dat matre, have no deſpaire, to effect in time dis great benefit, and dat vil make a de law flouriſh; and Englan a brave Englan, begar.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I won't doubt your abilityes, but I feare the capacity of the Gentlemen you undertake.

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: But what will you look for now, for your paines Mounſieur? that is conſiderable.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar me looke for very muſh, for tis muſh paine, and tis brave ting, beſide me looke for a ſtatur of de braſſe, in de pallace yard, ven me goe out of dis varle.

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: You will deſerve it as a rare patriot; but what manner of reverence would you have the grave lawyers to Imitate, you muſt conſider their robes:

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Obſerve a me.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Such a reverence under your favour, would not become men of their gravity, one alwayes lookes for a Coranto after it, and provokes a man to whiſtle, or fing when he ſees it, and makes one thinke ſtill, what you would have a moneth, a little too much of the activity.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar you no underſtand de matre, vere is your breine? dere is noting in de varle like a dat motion, for de Ientillman, and for de Ientilvoman.

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p:
Yes by your leave ſir there is ſomething
elſe that is as good for them.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: I vil tell you now, begar, here is a de kinſman dat is a me, and he live here very much time, before he come, dey vent in vid deir toes, and hold der cloke juſt a dere, and de hat ſo, fie, le diable! and now dey valk vid deir toes out for brave genty, you call dat a de ſplay foot, but me vonder dat de Lady no come, begar me no uſe to dis patience, and de vaite, pray tell you Madam dat me have autre buſines vid de Lor, and de autre Lady have de uſe of my foot begar.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Oh Monſieur by no means.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Let us prevaile.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Tis no good you hold a me, begar, me no ſtay two minute to ſave a your ſoule, dat is de reſolution of de Cavalier de France.— Exit

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Would any man beleeve there ſhould be ſo much folly in this Cubit ſquare?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Do you think he is a French Dancer? let that anſwer you, and wonder he has no more Caprichios. But theſe Ladies are very tedious, we muſt have this Lecture put down.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: They are more like to purchaſe Greſham Colledg, and enlarge it for publick Profeſſors, you may live to ſee another Univerſity built, and only women commence Doctors.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: But now we talk of learned women, you have been acquainted with Miſtris Voluble, has ſhe the abilities the women talk of? they ſay ſhe is a Fortune-teller.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p:
She is for more then Artificiall VVhite and Red, ſome think her guilty of the Black-Art, ſhe has foretold ſo many ſtrange things; ſhe has had two Husbands, and propheſied long before, how,
and when they ſhould give up the Ghoſt, if ſhe be not a Witch ſhe has the more wrong, for ſhe is beleev'd a devilliſh cunning woman.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Poſſible!

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: There's no • a Lady with child but conſults her Aſtrology, whether it ſhall be male or female; and the waiting women how long they ſhall keep their maidenheads, and who ſhall father the firſt borne, the Maſter or the ſervingman; ſhe is held a Sibill in the City, and tells oraculouſly whether the Husband or the VVife ſhall die firſt, how, when, and where, and all this ſometime by obſervation of the hand, or forehead; ſhe can ſee a maid through a maske, and is excellent at ſtolne goods, for ſhe can ſee a theefe through a millſtone as well as a conjuring glaſſe; in brief, ſhe is held prodigious at Divination, and moſt ſpecially ſeldome failes in her Judgment of the two deſtinies, Matrimony, and Hanging, this I have heard Sir.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Sr William Your Servant, Maſter Newman? that's he.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Jeere him ſoundly.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: VVhat Gentlemen are theſe?

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: He has betraid his ignorance already, he does not know us.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: VVhat, not the Major, and the Minor?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Not the Major, nor the Minor.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Cede majori Sir, Cede majori.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Parce minori Sir, Parce minori.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Here will be a fine concluſion from theſe premiſes, and they were worth conſidering.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Theſe two are wits.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: Are they your wits? Pray heaven you may not loſe 'em.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: If you love wit obſerve a little, and if I do not make you laugh, never laugh while you live.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: I thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: You ſhall here how I will jeere Newman, my Rivall now; ſuch wit, wit of the laſt Edition: Let me have faire play, and theſe moſt ingenious friends of mine ſhall be judges.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: I think ſo, 'twill paſſe time till the Ladies come.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Mr Newman, you are a pretty Scholler, pray what is wit?

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: A thing you want.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: A very pretty Probleme.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: VVill you or theſe Gentlemen be bound to underſtand me?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, that's a clinch, to underſtand me.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: A clinch?

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: I underſtand none.

sp.speaker: Simpl.
sp.p: Oh ſir, a palpable clinch; Ha, ha, ha, aske my friend.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Is that your opinion?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Theres another clinch yfaith, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Pray ſir, what is't a clock?

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: The myſtery of this?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: VVhat is a clinch ſir, do you know what 'tis?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
I neither know, nor care what 'tis, ſo I laugh, and ſweare 'tis a clinch, that's diſgrace and reproach enough to any man. With what eaſe can we cry up our own wit and anothers down, only by
ſaying that's a clinch. I think I ha jeerd him.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Oh the waies to wit are much ſhortned in theſe latter times, 'tis a picant age.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They have a gunpowder-plot to blow up ſence; pray Gentlemen take truce with your ſpleenes, and the wiſeſt of you three informe me what is wit; you have; no patience to heare me; or if you will not define it, ſpeake ſomething that is witty, and in faſhion.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Ile tell you then:

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: You ſpeak Engliſh to be underſtood, O baſe!

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: VVhat language is your wit?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Engliſh, but elaborate, for example—now beat up your kettle drums.

sp.speaker: 1 Jer.
sp.p: Sir, if my opticks faile not, I have read
Each myſtick line within your brow, my Genius
Is much exalted at your gaudy Phiſnomy;
Shal's to the houſe of mighty noiſe and ſurfets,
There tinctiour ſouls with bloud of purple grape?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: VVhat's all this?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Ha, ha, I thought you were ignorant.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Give him the Paraphraſe.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: All this is, he remembers perfectly he has ſeene you before.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: And deſires you but to go to the Tavern, and drink a pint of wine; here's language!

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Is't poſſible?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: VVhat a deale of Embroydery is ſpent upon I am glad to ſee you well; How long has this been a vulgar language? You would court a Miſtris rarely in this Cabale.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: But how ſhall a man beget ſuch high conceits?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Have you a deſire to know Sir William? ſhall I tell him?

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer
sp.p: If he will make it a ſecret.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Why, turne your ſelfe round as faſt as you can, and the firſt things you ſpeak, your head being diſſie, will be theſe.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What a beavy of Buffoons have we here?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: VVe are at your mercy Gentlemen; but you that had a patience to expect ſo long, cannot want vertue to forgive, ſince we had no intent to make ſo great a treſpaſſe; where's Monſieur Galliard?

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Madam, he's gone, ſomething diſpleas'd you had no more regard to a Gentleman of his quality; his time was pretious, and ſome other Lords and Ladies expected him.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: His abſence will admit of eaſie pardon, 'tis a moſt ſuperſtitious foole; what Gent. are theſe?

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: They are things were meant by nature, Madam, a cure for melancholly, we have had ſuch ſport and non-ſence with 'em

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: VVe ſhall loſe time upon 'em, pleaſe you, wee'l take a turne i'th Gallery.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Miſtris Lucy be tender-hearted to theſe Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They are only fit for your compaſſion.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: They are worth your acquaintance, Maſter Newman knows 'em; have not their wits a pretty edge?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Diſmiſſe your Beagles I ſhall beat you all three elſe, and monſtrouſly, indeed I ſhall; be rul'd, and keep your wits warme, I ſhall ſling out like winter.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I thank you ſir and you be in earneſt; I
proteſt Major, and Minor, the man's in wrath, away.
How now Iames.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: I am glad I ha found you ſir, your mother's come to town, ſhe rode behind me.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Not too loud, where is ſhe? I would not have it known till ſhe have other cloaths, and better breeding.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: She's at your Lodging ſir.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Miſtris Ʋoluble, my mother's come by directions, mum, and make haſte; ſweet Miſtris Lucy, I beſeech you take it not unkindly if I depart.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: By no means noble ſir.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: This is my man that has brought me newes out of the Country forſooth.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: None of your Tenants dead I hope?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Some are Coppyholders, and I hope you wiſh me no harme, but I vow 'tis not my fault that I muſt take my leave ſo abruptly.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: You have a cheerefull licence ſir.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: As I hope to make new Leaſes, and ſell a hundred Acres of wood this Terme, I am very ſorry, but I will waite upon you in the Evening. Noble Mr. New.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Ha, ha, that's a clinch.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I am your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Another Clinch I proteſt. Ex. Sim:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Now we have opportunity I preethee Mrs Voluble for my ſake tell him his Fortune; I have been a ſ • tor to know your deſtiny.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: It will be a favour, it was in my ambition to deſire it.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: My Lady deſires your preſence in the gallery.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I muſt obſerve her command, but you may ſatisfie the Gentleman in my abſence, and Mr: Newman when you know how the ſtarres have determined of you, make not me a more ſtranger.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I ſhal be onely fortunate to be yours.
Now Miſtris Ʋoluble, if you be acquainted with my ſtarres, and know what fortune they decree me, I ſtand full prepared; what lines are in my forehead, you obſerve ſo?

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: Pray let me ſee your hand.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Freely command it.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: Some that doe make a trade of fortunetelling (which is beneath my practiſe) flatter mea for their baſe end of profit, Ile be plaine.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Truth loves no other habit, you prepare me to give you the more faith.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: Tis very ſtrange, but this is moſt propheticall, you are—

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: VVhat?

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: In love.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: 'Tis very likely.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: It may not prove ſo lucky, love is a malanchoy buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I thinke it be. Is this all you can tell by your art?

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: You would know your deſtiny.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: VVhat pleaſe my ſtarres and you?

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p:
Take this for oracle then, you will do ſomething in a melancholy humour will enda •
ger your neck.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: My necke? ſhall I be hang'd? better the witch were burn'd.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: Fare you well Sir. Exit.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: A pox a your prognoſtick, ſhe has put me
Into a ſweat, and I doe more than halfe

Beleeve ſhe is a witch, or worſe, in a melancholy humour; muſt I doe ſomething to endanger my necke? unth? I ſhall put my ſelfe into a deſperate melancholy with thinking on't; I will be mercy, 'tis time to laugh and ſing, thoughts doe not vex me to a new tune, ther's no way but to a Taverne, Ile ſeeke out company.

lg.l: Love by your leave a while, and lazy folly,
Sacke is the Antidote to melancholy.

div.head: Act. III. Scaena. I.
div.stage: Enter Simpleton, Mother (in riding cloathes) Mrs. Ʋoluble, fames.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: I Have obeyed you ſonne, but I ſhall never ſadge with theſe things you talke of.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Then y'are an aſſe, every childe can doe it.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: I, if I had been a Gentlewoman of a child, much might ha been done.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p:
Alas after a little time, you wil take pride every day of your ſelfe; I wonder this wench
comes not! what? your ſonne has a care of you, and 'tis never too late to learne to be a Lady; this maide I commend to you, is a very rare dreſſer to a pinne, and will keepe your linnen with all variety of ſweet bagges and powders, that can be imagined; and for your rich gownes, ſhe will preſerve 'em with the new faſhion-ſereclothes, and make them outlaſt Egyptian bodyes.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: But muſt my old Miſtris be a Lady? that will be fine ifaith.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: The Taylour has taken meaſure for a Lady I am ſure, and three or foure yards of Sattin, more than will ſerve for a Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Then ſhe mun be kirſtned, and call'd Madam.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Peace and harken to my Landlady.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: Beſides ſhe has the rareſt receits to deſtroy moathes, and ſuch a ſoveraigne medicine againſt fleas, that your maides need never to ſqueak as if they were raviſh'd, peeping into their ſmocks before they go to bed.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: That will be fine.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: The weneh I tell you on, knowes how to conſume Cornes too, and for fidelity about your box of teeth, falſe haire, your glaſſe eye.—

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: My Mother has two eyes of her owne, but that one ſquints.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p:
Then for all manner of Caudles, Aleberries, Poſſets, and preſerves in all kinds, and ſhould you lye in this maid will be the moſt diligent creature about warming of cloaths, and for brothes and gellies moſt excellent, and for all ſtrengthners of nature; then if any of your women be to apt to conceive any thing that is ill,
ſhe hath her drinkes of retention, and expulſion—but Madam

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: She is no Lady yet.!

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: Sir I ſpeake what I foreſee, and therefore among our ſelves, Madam agen, this maid is very diſcreet, you will know what that meanes, not troubleſom when your Ladiſhip would be private, nor ſuffer any elſe to trouble you, and beſide ſhe will never be in love, which is no ſmall matter for a waiting woman; ſhe is here already— Enter Nice. Mrs. Nice you are fortunate to be recommended, to attend this, (but a Gentlewoman yet.).

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: She is too fine.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Hold your prating, and heare my Landlady, have not you clothes to come home?

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: I ſhall think my ſtarres have been carefull of me, if I may have the happineſſe to ſhew my duty to ſo noble a Lady.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: She calls me Lady too.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: They know what will become on you.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Oh that I could ſpeake ſo gainely; I am but new come out of the Country, but if you pleaſe to be as good as your word, I will doe the beſt I can, to be thankfull, as they ſay.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: My mothers very raw, you muſt coddle her, you will have but a foule hand with her, doe you thinke ſhe will ever come to any good? the truth is, I am aſham'd on her, and therefore be not a knowne that ſhe is my mother, till you ha' diſciplin'd her, ſhe muſt live very privately.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: How ſhall her name, perſon and eſtate be publiſh'd? do not you meane to have her a Lady?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: By any meanes ſir, and let me be one of her Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: I have it; do you obſerve the maid I commended to her? She is a Gentlewoman alwaies bred among Ladies, and knows how to talk, and carry her ſelf, before any Knight or Lord in the Court: What, if for the more expedite way to your mothers inſtructions this wench ſhould take upon her ſometime to be her Miſtris, and in her name, before ſtrangers, exerciſe ſome pride and courtſhip? 'tis a neerer way by example than precept to arive at any thing; and by obſerving her Faſhion, Garbe, and Language, your mother may be ſooner ripe for a Ladiſhip by at leaſt two months, beſide all the rules ſhe may receive from us in private.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Admirable! My mother is a towardly old woman.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Old? you do not know how painting may transforme Age; and the wench is not ſo young as ſhe ſeems; howſoever this will be only to ſtrangers, and you may with more reputation own her for your mother among Gallants, 'tis but ſaying ſhe was married at twelve, and you pop'd into the world before thirteen.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I will leave her to your tuition, and this Gentlewomans education.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Then 'tis thus Madam, come hither Nice.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Iames, thou ſhalt wait upon me to my Miſtris when thou haſt better cloaths.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: I have a new ſuite coming up from top to toe.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
Ile never live in the Country agen, ſuch another clod was I when I came to London; mother
you muſt be dutifull, 'tis for your own good; but do you heare Landlady, have you ſpoke the powerfull word to my Miſtris? Shall I have her from Newman?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I have read his deſtiny, and if things hit with his credulous nature, he will make himſelf uncapable of her affection; you are the next in preferment, never feare it, and leave your mother to our method and government, we will both edifie, and Ladifie her.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: With all my heart: buoy Lady mother.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: If pleaſe you wee'l withdraw; you muſt be ſecret Iames. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Manly (in Leiſters habit) the two Ieerers meet him.

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer:
sp.p: What have we here?

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: The Ghoſt of Leiſter?

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.l: Thus I have ſeen him painted,
'Tis ſome humorous Gentleman.

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: A proper fellow?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: It is not dark enough; how they gape at me?

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: Let's make ſport with him, he ſhews admirably by twilight, he has not travelled far ſure; ſuch a ſhape would get money in Bartholmew Faire.

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: Are you a high German ſir?

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: Yes, 'tis a Fencer; did you not heare of a Swiſſe that came over to be beaten at eight ſeverall weapons?

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p:
By your favor ſir, no, 'tis no high German, thoſe breeches are not worne in Switzerland,
there is ſomething of the codpiece—

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: 'Tis not His Majeſties Operatour for the Teeth, that hangs about Fleet-bridge.

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: He's not ſo hanſome.

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: Were not you one of the brothers that guarded the Dyall at Bow Church, and us'd to put Cheapſide in mind of their quarters?

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: No, he wants a Pollaxe; do you think he came not off ſome Conduit?

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: I am ſure he came not off o'th' ſaltſeller, He is a ſize too tall.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Theſe rogues will draw a Regiment of Prentices about me preſently, and then ſhall I be apprehended for ſome ſea monſter, and thrown into the Thames at the next Staires, to ſhew their worſhips how well I can ſwim—have you any thing to ſay to me?

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: 'Tis Engliſh that he ſpeaks, he is one of us.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I am one that will venture to beat you both in the ſame language, if you leave me not the ſooner.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: 'Tis ſome that skulkes in this diſguiſe for debt; we'l ſay we are Officers, and pretend to arreſt him.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Nay then have at you bandogs—
sp.stage: Enter Newman, and Gentlemen, (their ſwords drawn.)
sp.p: A reskue?

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: Hold.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Down with the Bayliffes, arreſt a Gentleman in the Kings high way— Ex. Manly

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.p: So, ſo, he is eſcap'd. Ex. Gent.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p:
You curſed tadpoles, cannot a Gentleman
walk i'th' ſtreets, but ſuch Tenterhookes muſt catch him by the cloak?

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: Noble Maſter Newman, we are your ſervants; do not you know us? we are no officers.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.l: Ha? If my opticks erre not, I have read
Each myſtick line within your brows,
Ye ſhall both—

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: Have our skins cut into meaſures.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: To the Taverne with me.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: We will be drunke together.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: You ſhall command us..

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: At my new Taverne where the wine ſhal flow as at a Coronation; fifty Fiddles, and a noiſe of Trumpets come along with me; you two ſhall ſend your tickets out for wenches.

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: Of all complexions, and degrees, from the Madam Alamode, to the humble Waſtcoteere. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I beſeech you Mrs Lucy make not me the Author, I affect Mr Newman, but this I receiv'd from good intelligence.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I am miſerable; I did not think his nature could degenerate into ſo wild a change, it is ſome witchcraft, I muſt grieve for him though I dare not ſhew it.

sp.speaker: Fo.
sp.p: Ther is a report, I would be loath you ſhould name me in't, but they confidently ſay; I dare not juſtifie upon my knowledge, that he has kild—

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Good heaven defend; then I am more undone.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Nay, theſe are the fruits of wine and ſurfets; I did not ſee him bleed, but I heard it from a man of quality, and one that had been Collector in the Pariſh, who told me for certaine that Mr Newman did kill him.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Whom? my afflicted heart.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: It was an Oſſicer that was ſlaine.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: The more unpardonable.—VVhere?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: In the Pariſh of Alhallowes Barking, the Bell man never dawnd ſince, comming drunk out of a Taverne at twelve—he made no more adoe—there was not ſuch another dog within the VVals; it waited upon the foreſaid Bell-man a nights in His Majeſties ſervice, to waken the Pariſh, and all day was hir'd out by a Blind-man, that beg'd, with a Bell about his neck.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Is that all the murder he has committed?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: All? you do not conſider the blind Begger that's undon by't, or who ſhall carry the Lanthorne at midnight, to light Gentlemen to the beſt Ale, and a Bawdy-houſe; but for my part Ile be no evidence, if the City will ſuffer ſuch an injuſtice within their VValls I can be ſilent, and think.

sp.speaker: Lu.
