sp.p: VVould this were all the danger, but I ſeare ſince he took up this rudeneſs and ſtrange carriage he may deſerve more ſorrow.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I love not to meddle in other mens affairs, but I know ſomething.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: I prethee tell me all.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p:
The Taverne he frequents he has made his Pheater at his own charge to act intemperance; o're the great Roome be uſes to be drunk in, they ſay, he has built a heaven, a Players heaven,
and thence a Throne's let down, in which, well heated, ſucceſſively they are drawn up to the clouds to drink their Miſtris health, while the mad mortals adore their God of Grape, and gaping look like earth that's chap'd with heat, although before within three minutes they were drench'd.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Doſt know that place?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You ſhall excuſe me, I know nothing.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Prethee be not ſo cautious, I am his friend, and pity him; if for my ſake thou woo't but find him out, and tell him I deſire to change but a few words, truſt me, I may amply requite this ſervice.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You muſt then keep ſecret what I undertake, Ile do't. Be cautious to whom you ſpeake, we muſt be circumſpect. I will go off inviſible. Exit.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Monſieur Galliard, my Lady expects you.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar me no like a dat reverence, me vil change a dat:

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: 'Tis the French faſhion as you taught Me Monſieur.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Ouy, tis de French faſhion, but de French faſhion is alwaies to change, and dis reverence diſpleaſe a me very muſh, becauſe you go back, back vid your buttock, as if ſome vod take you by dat, to vat me vil give a no name.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Monſieur Galliard my Ladie will be here preſentlie.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Sweet Mrs Lucie.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Dat de reverence is no good of de man, me muſt change dat too; by me trot me doubt dat dis great buſineſs vil almoſt break a my braine,
dis great varke, and before a maske of de King and de Queene, me can eate a no meate, no drinke, no ſleepe, and me growe ſo very a leane, vid de contemplation, a ſo much, by my trot de privy counſell is no ſo much troubled as me be vid dis, oh, le Diable! deirs is noting, dey ſit all the vile dey doe deir buſines, me biſſey bo'te head, and de foot cap a pie, in de french tune, and dat is great matre begar.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: You eſteeme it highly Mounſieur.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me tell you, and me tell you no tale, tis great matre to make a de Lor, to make a de Lady, to make a de Gentleman, to make a de Gentilvoman, and de autre man to dance, and to make a de good reverence, for begar dat vil make a de King, de great kin in de varle.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: How can that be Sir?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me tell you, ven dey are ſo biſſey, to learne a de dance, dey vil never tinke of de Rebellion, and den de reverence is obedience to Monarchy, and begar obedience is ale de ting in de varke.

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: I'le ſweare your ſtate affaires ly in your foot, and you are wifer there, than ſome heads are, and may be a preſident for after ages; but what muſick would you governe the people by?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar by de beſt french fidles can be got?

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: What thinke you of an Iriſh harpe, a ſtate organ, or a paſtionate voyce to a lovers lute?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Des dull tings make a de men melancholique, and den dey tinke on de Devill, and de
treaſon, and do any ting dat is no good, but begar des french fidles doe fidle all deis tings out of deir head, vid ſuch a Jearke, as ma foy make a dem ſo phantaſticall, and make a dem as good ſubject, as any is in de France begar.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I muſt waite upon my Mother.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: She will be here immmediately.—
She is not right yet.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Here be one of my coliers, Mounſieur Simplaton, ſay you no dat de french fidle make a de brave government in de varle?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I ſay any thing becomes a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Obſerve you dat? he have been but two are mont and he ſay any thing, dat is very brave? he have de grand underſtanding in de foot; tell a me, ven you heare a de little fidell, vat is your tinke? is your head no free from de treaſon, and plot of de rebell, as your leg? begar you no ſtand upon de ground for Joy of de Coran, de Cerebran, de Marquiſs, de Mountague, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: My Lady.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me be your humble ſervant Madam, and ſtay one two tre houre.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I am now ready for you Mounſieur, come Lucy the practiſe of the laſt he taught us.

div.stage: Lady and Lucy dance, Mounſieur ſinging, and correcting them in tune.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: The Gentleman you expect Sir VVilliam is come.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Madam prepare your ſelfe for mirth, 'twill be a ſight beyond the pageants.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Wee'l not be ſeen at firſt, Lucy withdraw.— Exit Lady and Lucy.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: What meanes this flouriſh? have you a play in hand?

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.l: To bid your excellence welcome to this lodging.
Fore Jove he lookes prodigiouſly, vouchſafe
Us th' honor of your hand.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ha!

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Vat Antick be dis?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: One of the ſupporters of the Brewers Armes.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, does he take upon him to be a Prince too, and will he ſpeake?

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: Theſe Ladyes have ambition to kiſſe your hand, and have a great deſire to know, how fares the campe at Tilbury, and pleaſe your Excellencie.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: 'Tis one of Arthurs Knights of the round Table.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: VVith his circular ſippets; would you thinke that a pigmy poiſon'd ſhould ſwell thus?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I am betraid, there's no retreat with honour, I muſt be confident.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Laugh and Jeere him hanſomely.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Oh that the Major, and the Minor had been here now, they would teeze him ifaith, Mounſieur, aske that Maypole and he can dance.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Plait il Mounſieur? a la Galiard, de Goran, la Princeſſe, le Buckingham, heigh!

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Put up your roſin, and your catsguts
preſently and be gon, or I ſhall finde a grave for you in the pocket of my ſleeve, and this ſhal be your winding ſheet.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me no play dat leſſon, pocket de ſleeve, dat is no tune de France, poket, le grand pock:— (Manly offers to ſtrike him) pardonne moy Mounſieur: me put up my fidell and be gon, adieu Madam, Serviteur gentilhomes; pocket de ſleeve? Exit.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But I muſt not ſeeme angry, Lady, my buſineſſe is to you.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Buſineſſe to me?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I am bold to preſent a ſute to you, I confeſſe it was not made by a French Tailor, I can make a leg and kiſſe my hand too after the faſhion of my cloaths, this ſerv'd in thoſe honeſt dayes, when Knights were Gentlemen, and proper men tooke the walls of dwarfes; here's a belly peece, that lookes like armour, with what comelineſſe may a man unbutton his dublet, when he ſeemes to take the wall to make urine? your ſleeve ſo neere your noſe, with a handkerchiefe, which I take out thus with a grace, after Emunction, I put up agen, with the corianders hanging out, Geometricall breeches in ſeverall ſliſes, in which a man is not aſham'd of his thighes, nor hides his bow leggs, which at the bottome ſurrounded with points make him look like a roughſooted Pigeon, theſe things were worne when men of honor flouriſh'd, that tam'd the wealth of Spaine, ſet up the States, help'd the French King, and brought Rebellion to reaſon Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: So they doe now.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Peace pepper corne; and all this at leſſe charge than a maſque comes to now, with the rare and new invention of hobbiehorſes; which of our two habits (be you Lady, but the indifferent Judge, and ſquint not,) is the more grave and manly, his leane upper chinne, or this goodly promontory? my Trunkes with a round walke pav'd with gold and ſilver, or your trouſes, cut cloſe to your dock, and drawne on with a ſcrew? in which if you venture but halfe a crowne, lookes like a poltiſſe, or a ſwelling in the groine; your habit is phantaſticall as the time, you ſquirt into your dublet, which you weare ſo careleſſe as you had not button'd it ſince you came from a bawdy houſe, where men of this garbe, coming from the ſtewes, march with that gravity as they came from a conventicle, ſo ſoherly they would carry it.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I ſee whoring was equall in all times, onely the carrying of it.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why that's all?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: But ſurely I doe wonder, how my Grandfather could kiſſe my Grandmother, or embrace in that ſtrange apparell.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: They made a ſhift Knight, or elſe your wiſe worſhip had not been here; but that I want ſo much beard, I could ſhew how your Grandfather ſtroak'd his three or foure handfull of haire, to the terrour no doubt of the ſtanders by, and could ſtab I warrant you, with his two handed beard then, as well as you with your dagger beard now. It was never a good time ſince theſe cloaths went out of faſhion; oh, thoſe honourable dayes and perſons!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Is't poſſible?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: As how?

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: I pray inlarge your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: To have ſeene but a St. Georges feaſt then.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Why, what difference ſir?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: When they were inſtall'd, to ſee the twenty mile to Windſor ſtrow'd with blewcoates, feathers and cognizances, as they do country townes with boughes, and flowers for Princes Entries, and not to go privately in a coach, with a page and a barber to cut off charges.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: How doe you like this Gentleman, Is't not a pretty humour?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Then you ſhould have the beſt knight of the Countrey, with the ragged ſtaffe on their ſleeves.

lg.l: The Beare, the Boare, and Talbot with his tuskiſh white,
Oh ſo ſore that he would bite,
The Talbot with his Tuskiſh white
Soudledum Soudledum;
The Talbot with his Tuskiſh white Soudledum, bell.
The Talbott with his Tuskiſh white
Oh ſo ſore that he would bite
Orebecke ſoudledum, ſing orum bell.

sp.p: Every Knight had his hundreds, and theſe would take up all the Tavernes in the Towne, be druoke to the honour of their Lords, and rather than not pay their reckoning, pawne their chains, though they pawn'd ſomething for them the night before, and ſuch merry catches then, as

lg.l: The Hart loves the high wood,
The Hare loves the hill,
The Knight lov'd his bright ſword,
And the Lady lov'd her will.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: So the Ladies do ſtill.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: It may be ſo, but for your Knights bright Sword 'tis at pawn, or at home in his Armory; then we had, God bleſſe the Duke of Norfolke, there was a jeaſt, and another Song.

lg.l: The great Choe bent,
The little Choe bent,
Sir Piercy leigh under the line;
God bleſſe the good Earle of Shrewsbury
For he's a good friend of mine.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: He's very confident.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Alas, he is compel'd to't.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: How do you like this Mrs Lucy, is he not a pretty ill-favour'd Gentleman in this habit?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: He ſings rarely.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: No queſtion he can dance too, in that diſguiſe he lookes like famous Cardell the dancing. Maſter in Queen Elizabeths time, I have ſeen his Picture.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And he with your Worſhips favour, was held a wiſe man, and for his gravity he might have been Treaſurer, he went with that ſetled and ſolid Pian-piano.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p:
And when he danc'd a meaſure, you ſhould have had him with his Rapier, ſhort Cloak,
his black Cap, and his white Feather, his ſingle and double, both backward and forward, with that excellencie—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: And now he muſt be in Cuerpo, or like a fellow on the ropes, or a Tumbler when he ſhoots his body through a hoop; there was muſick then, and a Heaven and Earth, beyond your braules, or your Mountague, with a la, la, la, like a Bachanalian dancing the Spaniſh Moriſce, with knackers at his fingers.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: It muſt needs be a rare ſight.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: He plaid to himſelf on a grave Lute, or a modeſt Citterne, with a politick quill, far beyond your Geofrey fiddle, or your French kit, that looks like a broken fagot ſtick, at the biggeſt, and ſounds as if it had got the French diſeaſe, when it ſnivels out a Coranto, or ſo hoarſe with a cold, as if ſome great baſe Fiddle had filenc'd it.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: What miſery is it, the Monſieur is gone now? here had been a French Duell.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: But had you ſeen my Lord Loftie dance the Galliard, with ſuch capers, ſuch half capers, ſuch turns o'th toe, and above ground, you would have ſworn 'em ſound for nine Generations, and for Lavaltoes, La, la, la, &c. and then the Lady.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: How did he uſe her?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: With wonderfull skill, he put his right arme about her, and took her leſt hand in his, and then he did ſo touze her with his right thigh and legg, and liſt her up ſo high, and ſo faſt, and ſo round—

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: As what I pray, be curteous.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
Marry as ſoon as he had ended his dance ſhe would lye down as dead as a ſwing'd chicken,
with the head under the wing, ſo diſſie was ſhe, and ſo out of breath; and all theſe wonders were extant Knight when this old Cap was new.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Is not this very fine ſport Madam?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir, y'are welcome; pray excuſe me, if being prepar'd for ſome folly, your garbe and perſon ſeem'd at firſt ridiculous; you have chang'd my opinion, and there wants but ſuch a noble leader to reduce, and make this habit faſhionable; it ſhews a proper man, and if I were worthy to adviſe, or could lay an obligation upon you, I ſhould take it for an honour if you would often viſit me in theſe ornaments, I like 'em infinitely, and the Wearer ſhall be ever welcome; pleaſe you wee'l walk and talk a turn in the Gallery.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You too much grace me Madam.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.l: How's this?
I have wound my ſelf into a pretty buſineſs,
She neglects me.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: In my judgment 'tis an indifferent pretty fellow, but that his cloaths are out of faſhion.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: They are moſt becomming; I do not like your new phantaſticall ſhapes, that transforme a man from his maſculine aſpect; you appear to me like a Jackanaps; there's a waſte, and a Long lane cut cloſe to your hanches. Exit.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
Hum! ſhe takes after the old one, I will try and ſhift my ſelf, if the mother be taken with the habit in Qu. Elizabeths daies, why may not the daughter affect that in K. Jameſes, and ſo the humor run in a bloud? I am reſolv'd; ſhe loves ſinging too, I am furniſh' with Ballads, o'my conſcience
this will do't; Ile fit her with a faſhion, and about it preſently. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: They are here agen, and laugh at me: How familiar the Turtles are?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bea.
sp.p: Wee'l taſte ſome aire i'th' garden, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: So, ſo, if I did love this widow for her ſelf, what a caſe were I in? but I muſt not ſit down thus, and ſomething muſt be thought on for my honour. Exeunt.

div.head: Act. IIII. Scaene I.
div.stage: Enter Miſtris Voluble, and Nice, (having a Jewell.)

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: SO, ſo, thou doſt carry it excellently, it ſpreads like a Proclamation, what a rich widdow lies at my houſe, her wealth, and wit, muſt be exercis'd.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: She muſt not appeare to be herſelf yet but in private, and the Chiauſe her Son has beſtow'd this Jewell upon me for expedition, for he dares not yet acknowledge her; ſhe wonders at herſelf now ſhe is painted, & ſweares in her conſcience ſhe looks by her glaſs like one of foure and twenty, and ſimpers, and licks her leatherne lips as ſhe had eaten Marmalade.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Sir William has heard of her, and (upon ſome affront, as I conjecture receiv'd from my Lady) has writ to me, and articled already to diſpoſe her affections, I expect him every minute.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: He will diſcover us.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: He ſhall never ſee thee act her part.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Do you thinke he can affect her?

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: Courtiers do not marry into the City for love, and this Farmers wife has wealth enough to Enter Simpleton, and James, (with his cloaths.) buy a Ladiſhip; here's the gull, away and be diligent. Exit Nice.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: They'l fit you as well as my ſelf for whom they were made in the Countrey.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: How now ſir, preparing for a race?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Is no body elſe with you? Do not enquire what ſtratagem is in hand, there be more waies to catch a Miſtreſſes heart; how does my mother?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: She is pretty apt for one of her yeares: I can tell you news, there is a Knight about her already.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: She ſhall have him.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Not with your favour if a greater perſon Interpoſe, I have ſo much care of her honour, now ſhe is my charge.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Miſtris Voluble, here's a Footman, lac'd all over, enquires for you, he ſerves a French Lord, he ſaies he muſt needs ſpeak with you, he has a letter. Exit.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: What if this Lord come hither for the ſame purpoſe?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p:
Tis too much happineſſe; Ile not be
ſeen thus, nor let my Mother appeare in her roughcaſt, uſe the Footman kindly, if his meſſage concerne us, away— Exit Ʋol.
And will this Faſhion become me, doſt thinke? I prethee tell me ſome old ſtories in to'ther raigne, thou canſt talke and make me ready too.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Ah ſir, I knew a time, when two and twenyeares was but a merry Chriſtmas, nothing but Ambaſſadors, Maſques, Playes, Entertainements, Hawking, Hunting, Winter and Summer, New-Market and Roiſton mourne now, ha! had you ſeen the Court fox'd upon Gouries night, and the Gunpouder treaſon began then; oh we had rare ſport, and then every body was knighted, they hardly leſt a Gentleman in thoſe dayes; and afterward they got a tricke of making Lords.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: For what?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I know not that, but they hardly left a Knight, man, woman, and childe were made right honourable.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Right honourable, right worſhipfull, and well beloved, I have heard that in the Countr • y.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: But the faſhion of welbeloved is left off, for we doe not now love one another.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: But had you no misfortunes?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Faith Sir, a rainy day was the worſt, and that had but made the ground more ſoluble the next day for hunting.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: No complaints James?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p:
Oh yes ſir! I hard a Gentleman complaine mightily that he had loſt the higheſt flying taſſell gentle, that ever was ſeene, another that he had
prick'd his grey Nag, that was an excellent buckhunter; a third, that he had fretiſh'd his beſt hound, Beauty, and that Lilly was kill'd at a Bay a ſtag-hunting, it had almoſt coſt the Genleman his life.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: And what elſe James?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: By my troth ſir, a Gentleman waiter, that ſhall be nameleſſe, removing a paſty of Veniſon, ſpilt it all, on a new ſatten doublet, and ſpoiled it utterly, there was ſuch laughing, but his Maſter being gracious gave him a ſute for his doublet, I thinke it was a Knight; but the Knight market is riſen now.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I and the Lord Market too, James.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: And pleaſe your worſhip, they ſay, the Herald would not make a Gentleman now, under ten pound.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Oh yes, they'l take reaſon to my knowledge, and give the prettieſt phantaſticall armes, I have all the colours of the Rainebow in my new coate, every foole may be a Gentleman of three generations now.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I can derive my ſelfe knave three deſcents under your anceſters.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Then thy children may write themſelves knaves of blood, take that upon my Heraldry; but had not you brave ſongs then James?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p:
In thoſe dayes was the quinteſſence of ballads, you went to ſchoole with 'em, I remember and learn'd no other bookes, I ſhall never forget the Lord of Lornes ſonne in Scotland and the falſe ſteward, to the tune of greene ſleeves, thoſe were the dayes indeed, oh there was then ſuch a company for dancing ſinging and fooling, I doe
not meane the wits, for ſooling is another thing cleare from it; It does ſo bravely in company, when there is a great many that care not for wit, and pleaſes better than all the wit in the world; and then there was ſuch brave jeaſts, at the death of a Stag, and Buck; to throw blood up and downe, upon folkes faces; the very Footn en and Pages underſtood thoſe Jeaſts then; there was a time; and the Landerers were as well Employed in a progreſſe then as now, and the Surgeons got as much by 'em too; oh, I ſhall never forget thoſe times.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: So, ſo, how doe I looke in this transformation? will any body know me doſt thinke? Miſtris Lucy, ſhall have the firſt ſight of my ſhape; ſome body is gone into the dining roome, let us out at the backe doore James. Exeunt.

div.stage: (Enter Nice. (dreſsing the Mother, painted) (at another Doore) Mrs. Ʋoluble.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: 'Tis well done Nice to be carefull about your Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: I am giving her ſome inſtructions about dreſſing, and was ſaying, ſhe muſt not goe above once to court in black, it would be very ſcandalous without intermixing colours, in her petticote, ſleeves, and ſtomacher, and the colours now in faſhion are blew, pincke, and incarnadine, yellow is much worne too.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: But 'tis very materiall, what lace you wil chooſe, as ſilver and gold for blew, (Tha • 's a court maxime) and plaine ſilver for incarnadine, ſingle or mixt will ſerve for pincke colour.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: I ſhall never remember all this.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: It is your Gentlewomans duty to remember.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Let me alone Madam. When you will keepe houſe, a long handkercheife, or a round one with a quaife tied under your chin, and a little haire curl'd, with a black taffa ta hood, or white ſarfenet.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: When you pretend to have a cold, you muſt ſhew no haire, but weare a forehead cloth, with a pinner over that, theſe cloathes are much worne by old Ladyes, with which they binde downe a peece of ſea recloth upon their forehead, to keepe wrinckles in obedience. How is her haire?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: That little that ſhe has is crazie.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: She has enough to curle, and you have the diſcretion to know what proportion is to be leſt out, according to the latitude of her face; and to be curl'd with pinnes and orrice pouder, which will neither hurt nor breake it, and then in the Morning to let the combe paſſe through it once, and open it, between a curle and a freeze, and draw up ſome of the curles with a bodkin within the other haire.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: My haire will never indure all this.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: You muſt endure more, if you meane to be a Lady of faſhion, and attractive; where be the pendants?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Muſt ſhe not weare a Feather?

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: Not without a diamond bodkin; have you no Jewels?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Yes, In the knot of my handkerchiefe.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: Oh fie, you muſt buy a Cabinet. What's here? a Toad ſtone, two Turkies, ſixe thumbrings, three Aldermens ſeales, five Gemmals, and foure Deaths-heads; theſe are Alehouſe ornaments—Yet theſe Diamonds are tollerable, and theſe Pearles will make a half Chaine.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Would ſhe were hangd in the fellow, condition we had the reſt.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: They muſt be changd, but Nice may weare theſe til you get new, they will ſerve to practice in. (Knock within.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: There's a Coach at doore.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Ile pawne my ability the French Lord, 'tis about the time I gave directions to his Footman; for his entertainment, you muſt take upon you the rich widdow, and be you carefull to obſerve Mrs Nices Language, garbe, and behaviour, to men of his quality; your Rings and Jewels upon her will credit the cauſe, and perſon he comes to viſit, which is your ſelf, but under a vaile. Ile prepare his Lordſhip. Exit.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: This is all for your inſtruction; theſe rings fit me excellent well, and hereaſter you may take pride upon you by my example.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I hope I ſhall learne in time; but I ſhall be more than a Lady if I marry with a Lord.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Alas, I am but the Lady in the Play.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Now you put me in mind, I have ſeen pretty harlotry Ladies in a Country Play, ſo proud, and ſo knaviſh, one would have ſworn they had been women indeed.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p:
Hee's here, you muſt be modeſt, and obſerve your diſtance now; Is this the Lord? He
looks like an over-grown Monkey.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: What pretty fooliſh things ſome of theſe young Lords are?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip is bountifull; that is ſhe whom fame hath delivered to you; your honour may advance.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar dis riſh viddow looke young as my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Vol
sp.p: If my eyes be not in a miſt this is the French Dancer.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Vat is your name?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: He means to catechiſe her.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: I ſhall be happy if your Lordſhip pleaſe to own me by the title of your ſervant.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: You muſt learne to complement thus—'Tis Galliard ſure.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: She kiſſe very vel begar, ſhe have de Alamode touch of de lip ma foy; can you dance Madam?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I am now confirm'd.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Will he kiſſe me too?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Vat is ſhe?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: A Gentlewoman that attends me for the preſent.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Dat is a de reverence for de divel, ſhe look like a de wihch Madam, but me tell you Madam, for me love you very muſh in the little time, as any man in de varle; me be French Lor, and me have lodging in de autre ſtreet, Duke de Memorency my kinſman, and two tre hundred great Lors have loſe deir head in France begar for no matre, and me flye to Englan to ſave a me neck by me trot.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Were you guilty of any treaſon?

sp.speaker: Gal
sp.p: No more begar than your little ſelf.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: What is your eſtate?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar very grand eſtate in Orleance, me have two tre Lettre from de Cardinall, and he write a me, dat de King ſend for me to kiſs his hand: Now as me vas in de reſolution to take a de ſhip for France, me heare of you Madam in de Strand, and me very glad to marry you before me go preſently.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip is very briefe, but I find not my ſelf enclin'd to croſſe the Seas.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: The Sea, mary ſhield, Ile not ſee the ſalt water for any Lord in Chriſtendome, I, Ile rather be no Lady.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Who, how now inſolence, how dare you interpoſe?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Will you be ridiculous, and betray your ſelf now?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar you have de Gypſey complexion, and looke like de ſign of-de Robin Hood and maid a Marian.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Robin Hood in thy face, does he maid a Marian me?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: She is not worth your Lordſhips paſſion, I ſhall teach you better manners.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar you ſhall have muſh need of dat.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: My Lord, you did aske me if I could dance.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: The wench has found him.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Dere is noting in de varle for de Lady, like a de underſtanding in de foot.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: I cannot praiſe my own ability, but I admire the excellency of other Ladies, and ſhould be fortunate to meet with ſome Maſter in thafaculty, that would Inſtruct, and exerciſe me in private.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me love you de bettre for da • , begar no body exerciſe you in private but my ſelf, me teach you Alamode de Court dance, hold up your litel fingre you command a my foot.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip is too humble, it is an office would become one that is mercenary; I affect dancing infinitely, oh that we had but ſome muſick here; la, la, ra. (She ſings, Gal. draws out his Fiddle.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: • is comming out.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: What's that a bedſtaffe?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: It is a French pocket-piſtoll.

sp.speaker: Mo.
sp.p: Will he ſhoot it oft here? I could never indure a gun. Exit.

sp.speaker: Gal
sp.p: Forboon, brave, ah, dat is like a de Princeſs, Allez.

sp.speaker: N •
sp.p: You ſhall not be ſo publick in your graces to me; conceale your Fiddle tillſome private oppo • runity.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me underſtand.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: How does your Lordſhip like her? You have her in an excellent humour.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Kiſſe a me madam—hah? 'tis heaven? de Poet talke of de Nectar, begar here is it; me never drink de • vine blanke or de Claret, ſo me have but two tre drop divine from your lip—Metreſſe ſpeake a for me.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: The foole is extaſied; in his worſt condition he will ſerve for a husband; how he dances in a Net?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: He has money, and a Trade, he will ſerve wench.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: If me get dis riſh widdow, me cozen 'em both begar.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: Do you think he loves me indeed. Ex. Vol.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: You no tinke madam dat me be ſo hot in love, and do burne, dat my reine a do melt, as me vere in de oven, me need a go into de river preſantly to coole and vater my heart, vere is de Miſtreſſe de la Maiſon? Gone? dat is vel, dere is no honor like a dat, as you take a de litel aire in my Coach.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: I have not been abroad to day, but I dare truſt my ſelf with your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Oh Madam, a voſtre ſervice, now if me get a de Prieſt all is perfect.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Be all theſe Trunkes hers?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: We ha not ſtowage enough for half, ſhe is infinitely rich.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Haſt thou prepar'd her?

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: I find her very apt, 'tis her only ambition to be a Lady, a French Lord has her in chaſe, but I have delivered your character, and what priviledge ſhe may have by charter of her Knight.

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: I long to ſee her, is ſhe handſome?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: What ſhe wants in beauty and breeding, ſhe has in eſtate Sir.

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: That, that's enough, I can have beauty in other places, and will exceed what I condition'd for, if I proſper. I will have this Widdow in ſpight.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: How Sir William?

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: To ſpight the Lady Beaufield, and her Magog that affronted me; I would loſe no oportunity, a widdow muſt be taken in the pick; ſay I am come and commend me to the heavens, Ile make all good.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: To the heavens? will you dye before her?

sp.speaker: Sr Will.
sp.p: For that we muſt take our chance; thou ſhalt be ſure of a good leaſe for thy life, and deſtiny agree upon us afterward.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Shall I direct you?

sp.speaker: Sr Wil.
sp.p: Sha't be my evening, and my morning ſtar. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You too much afflict your ſelf Miſtris Lucy, 'tis but ſome humour he put on to try the ſtrength of your affection.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: He is loſt; not for my ſake, but for his own I pitty him, and I am confident, if I were ſo happy to ſpeak with him agen, I ſhould prevaile to win him to his firſt and noble temper; my end being ſo juſt, I could diſpence with modeſty to find him out, and perfect the act of charity.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: You have imployd Formoll, from whom you may expect to heare ſuch an account, as may dry up your ſorrows.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I ſee Sir you preſerve your confidence.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: I dare be juſt in your commands, and in a ſervice you but ſmile upon, deſpiſe the cenſure of the world.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Saw you not the Knight ſince?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: The ſweet hopes that he ſwallow'd, to prepare me a ridiculous object to you Madam, was gall upon his ſtomack, when he found you had mercy on my confidence; he dares not converſe with ſo unlick'd a beare, as this ſhape muſt preſent Enter Simpleton, and James. his criticall eye ſight. Whats here? one ſent to affront me?

sp.speaker: Simp.

lg.l: When Robin came to Nottingham dery, dery down,
His dinner all for to dine:
There met him fifteen • olly Foreſters,
Were drinking Ale, and Wine, hey down.

sp.p: Madam your moſt humble ſervant; there be other men, and manners, and garbes as faſhionable in the eyes of diſcreet Ladies.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Have we got Adam Bell, and Clim o'th Clough?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: We be three, good Mr William of Cloudeſly.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: 'Tis ſo.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: And how, and how ſhew matters Miſtris Lucy? every mans Cap is not made of the ſame matter.

l.hi: Have you felt the wooll of Beaver?
—Have you ſmelt of the bud of the Roſe?
—Or have taſted the bag of the Bee?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Sir, this is moſt uncivill, and your raſhneſſe, beſide the forfeit of your own diſcretion, will lay an imputation to wound my fame; within my preſence, and beneath my roofe, which ſhould protect all ſtrangers, to affront a Gentleman that viſits me—

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: How's this?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Be bold ſir, and preſume you have my favour, you never appear'd handſome till this minute; beare up, your mirth becomes you rarely.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Dos't iſaith?

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: What does my mother meane?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Spit o' thy hand, and clap me oth' ſhoulder Iames, the widow her ſelfe is in love with me.

lg.l: She caſt an eye on little Muſgrave
As bright as the ſummers ſunne.

sp.p: I may turne o're the Daughtet to thee.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I would I had her in an Embroiderd clout.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Sure my Lady is but in jeaſt.

lg.l: Shew me ſaid he whoſe men ye be
That hunt ſo boldly here,
That without my conſent do chaſe
And kill my follow Deere.—

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: His follow Deere?

lg.l: Ere thus I will out braved be
One of us two ſhall dye,
I know thee well an Earle thou art,
Lord Percy, ſo am I.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Thou Douglas?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p:
This Lady has but fool'd me all this while; make much of your new Antick Madam, I can ſhift into my ſelfe agen, and if that thing were worth my anger, or my envy, beate him;
you have a pretty humour, cheriſh it, and that William of the Wiſpe, till I viſit you agen.— Exit

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: The Gentleman is jealous.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I proteſt Madam if it had hot been not your ſake, and that it had been pitty to have ſpilt any blood, in your Dining roome, I would ha done ſomething

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: In his breeches.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: But I ſhall report your nobleneſſe abroad.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Doe not play the foole to much, I am out of the humour to laugh at you; he cannot leave me thus.— Exit Beau.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: This was no tricke to catch the old one.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: How came you into this habit Simpleton?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: By reading Ovids Metamorphoſis, and to ſhew the variety of my wit.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Let me entreat you hold your feet together,—now you put me mind of a Smiths bellowes, your body is not all of a peece ſure, but ſeverall limbes thruſt into ſeverall pudding bags, you would ſhew terrible to the crowes in a wheat field, you are no living creature.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Perſwade me to that, am I not ſenſible?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He that does that cure upon you, will deſerve a chronicle; ſo deſiring you would take home your flaile there, for here is like to be no thraſhing worke, I commit you to the Barne, where like another Orpheus, you will draw the horſe, and ſheepe, to the melody of your voyce, and raviſh all the Cowes in the Countrey, to heare you ſing Packingtons pound.— Exit.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: She has made a coxcombe on you.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p:
Hum? I wo'not out o'the pit for all this, I
have another deviſe, and thou ſhalt aſſiſt me, if that faile, I'le dye a bachelor, and make thee my heire.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I ſhall but pray for your death ſir.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.l: Back agen, back agen quoth the Pindar,
The wrong way have you go • , &c.

div.stage: A Table, Stooles, Bottles of wine, and Glaſſes, ſet out by two Drawers.—then Enter Newman, the two Jeerers, Wenches, Muſitians.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: So, ſo, I'le dance no more, a ſong, lets have a ſong now.

sp.speaker: 1 Wen.
sp.p: Take heed of the old ballads, eccliped, Like Hermit poore, eyes hide my love, or Panae in the brazen Tower.

sp.speaker: 2 Wen.
sp.p: Or the lamentable complaint of Ariadne, and Theſeus, and the more lamentable for being ſo long.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Doe you heare Madam vertue, Lady modeſty cannot you play your part?

sp.speaker: 1 Je.
sp.p: Not upon the violin.

sp.speaker: 2 Je.
sp.p: They are both for the Gambo.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: You ſhall play the part of my Miſtris, you muſt be witty then, and extreame coy and ſcurvy, in your anſwers; go behind that hanging, I will ſuppoſe it your chamber; now Boy the Song I made to the window, while I muſtle my ſelfe with the fidlers, to bid my Miſtriſſe good morrow in the ſtreet, obſerve the conjuration.

lg.l: I conjure thee, I conjure thee, by thy skin that is ſo faire,
Thy dainty curled haire,
And thy favour and thy grace,
With the patches on thy face,
And thy hand that doth invite
The cold, dulleſt appetite,
—Appeare appeare,
Ʋpon theſe termes I doe invite thee,
And if thou com'ſt I will delight thee.
If not ſo, I doe not care,
Though thy breaſts be ne're ſo bare,
Roſes rich, with shooe that's white,
Or thy Venus beſt delight,
If not touch thy ſofter skin
What care I for thee a pin,
Appeare appeare.
For to heare, and not to ſee
Is a dull flat hiſtory,
And to ſee and not to touch
If you thinke the laſt too much,
Know all woman's but one ioy
If we men not them enjoy,
Appeare appeare.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: She's not awake, play a ratling tune that may ſtartle her; where's this whore? ha!—

sp.speaker: 1 Jer.
sp.p: She's gone.

sp.speaker: 2 Jer.
sp.p: Vaniſh'd? ſo he might have ſung away his lungs.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: It may be, ſhe is retir'd, for you know what Lady; come let us drinke.

sp.speaker: 2 Wench.
sp.p:
Was your Muſe at all this expence
to the fidles? do you write to no other company ſir?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Till they have my liveries; Ile maintaine 'em in ſongs, wind up your voyce agen▪

lg.l: Thine eyes to me like ſunnes appeare
Or brighter ſtarres their light;
Which makes it ſummer all the yeare,
Or elſe a day of night:
But truely I doe thinke they are
But eyes, and neither ſunne nor ſtarre.
Thy brow is as the milky way,
Whereon the gods might trace:
Thy lips Ambroſia I dare ſay
Or Nectar of thy face:
But to ſpeake truely I doe vowe
They are but womens lips and browe.
Thy checke it is a mingled bath
Of Lillyes and of Roſes;
But here there's no man power hath
To gather loves freſh poſies:
Beleeve it here the flowers that bud
Are but a womans fleſh and blood.
Thy noſe a promontory faire,
Thy necke a necke of land;
At natures gifts that are ſo rare
All men amaz'd doe ſtand:
But to the cleerer judgement thoſe
Are but a womans necke and noſe.
For foure lines in paſſion I can dye
As is the lovers guiſe,
And dabble too in Poetry
Whilſt love poſſeſt, then wiſe
As greateſt States-men, or as thoſe
That know love beſt, yet live in Proſe.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: The pure ſpirit of Sack in't.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: The wits Elixar.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: No jeering Gentlemen, I ſhall grow loud and break the peace.

sp.speaker: 2 Wen.
sp.p: Theſe Gentlemen are for nothing but ſong and drink, I ſee no market all this while; Ile get me hence too; if pleaſe you, Ile ſee if I can find out my ſiſter. Ex. 2 Jeer.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: There's but one ſtoole in the counting houſe, and Lady you ſhall ſtay till ſhe returne; Gentlemen there's no life in you; I cannot do this roring and whoring handſomely; little thinks Lucy what Comrades I have got.

sp.speaker: 2 Wen.
sp.p: I have a pretious confidence in you Gentlemen, to truſt my ſingle modeſty amongſt ſo many.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: VVhat would you give to be raviſh'd now? thou haſt an excellent complexion for't.

sp.speaker: 2 Wen.
sp.p: Raviſh'd? preſerve the Gentlemans deare wits Sack I beſeech thee.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: You would not loſe by it if he raviſh you.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: another Song, and direct your voice to this Lady.

lg.l: I'de have her merry, laugh, and ſmiles
And then look grave and ſad:
In every humour but a while,
Make love as 'tis, that's made
I'de have your dreſſe of ſever all ſhapes,
Like Proteus carv'd, not he,
In humour a ſhe coy Jackanapes
Then a grave Monkey be.
Diſcourſe of all that comes to ſence,
But ſpeak none, yet ſtill ſpeak,
No matter here is no offence,
But to ſpeake matter weak.
With thy ſoft voice ſing me aſleep,
Then ſtartle me awake,
With Loves notes-paſsion make me weep,
Then merry for thy ſake.

sp.speaker: Jeer. Mi.
sp.p: A diſcovery?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What new-found Land?

sp.speaker: Jeer. Mi.
sp.p: The Pigeon that left us hath been in another roome with Mr Formall my Lady Beaufields Gentleman Uſher, there he ſits like the picture of a Harry Soveraigne in a chaire, while ſhe is picking on's pocket.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Fetch him, and his Fairy hither, but for his Mrs ſake uſher him with loud muſick. Ex. Jeer.
Wee'l have ſome ſport. (Flowriſh.

div.stage: Enter the two Jeerers, and Formall.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Where's the wench?

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: The wench has made an eſcape, ſhe had a glimpſe before and ſuſpected me, but here's the wicked Elder.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: What ſaies my wiſe▪ Lu • ullus?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Sir, my buſineſs was to you, though I met a Remera that is already ſunke, I was ſent by a Gentlewoman, but no body muſt know it.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: We heare no buſineſs till he have wound up a bottle, and then he ſhall have audience.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: That's but your fee for entrance, your garniſh only; come ſir there's no remedy.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I hope you will conceale it Gentlemen.

lg.l: Why then let us drinke,
Away skurvy thinke,
And do't till we winke;
Which is juſt to be
So drunke not to ſee.
Firſt Maudlin to weep,
Then after to ſleep;
Why they let us drinke,
And do't till we winke,
Away skurvy' thinke.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: VVhar will become of me? would you and I Lady were in a back roome.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: So now ſpeak my Lord Embaſſador, I know your ſoveraign Lady greets us well.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Alas ſir, my Lady does not know of my comming; I would ſpeak with you from one that ſhall be nameleſs, who thinks you are a debauch'd Gentleman, under the Roſe, and deſires to talk with you when you are ſober: I would be loath to diſgrace you before this good company, neither was I willing to tell her what I heard about your drinking and whoring.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: To the point.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: I, I, to the point.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: The principall matter then, and indeed my whole employment at this time to you is—

sp.speaker: New
sp.p: VVhat in the name of circumſpection?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: You ſhall excuſe me ſir, filence is a vertue; but if you knew who ſent me—

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: He would make a coſtive Stateſman.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: It is ſufficient one deſires to ſpeak with you, I name no time, nor perſon, I know my office; Miſtris Lucy is not to be named at all times.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Miſtris Lucie, I am her ſervant; come drink this narrow ſea to her health, you muſt be drunk inſallibly, Ile give a reaſon; I ſweare by Muſcadell That I do love her well; come yee Mermaids—

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Ile do you reaſon then; but is this Muſcadell? Mr Newman has ſworne; for my own part, Gentlemen, I deſire it ſhould go no further.

lg.l: I ſweare by Muſcadell
That I do love thee well,
And more than I can tell.
By the White, Claret, and Sack
I do love thy Black, black, black,
I do love thy black, black, black.
No Goddeſſe 'mongſt them all
So ſlender, and ſo tall,
And gratefull too with all,
Which makes my ſmews to crack
For thy black, black, black,
For thy dainty black, black.
So lovely, and ſo faire,
Though ſhaddow'd with thy haire,
So nimble, juſt like aire;
All theſe ſet me on loves wrack
For thy black, black, black,
For thy dainty black, black.
Thy kind and cunning eye,
When firſt it did eſpy,
Our love it did deſcry,
Dumbe ſpeaking, what d'you lack?
Mine anſwer'd, thy black, black,
Thy dainty black, black, blacke.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Excellent!

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Now give Mr Formall his cup.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I have had the narrow ſea, I cannot drink an Ocean.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: His t'other cup; you had my wench as I remember, and Ile preſcribe you a pennance; there's another whore for you, drink to her and ſhee ſhall pledge.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Give me thy hand, and ſet thy foor to mine.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: You may truſt your ſingle modeſty with him.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: For my own part, I had rather do things privately; come kiſſe me firſt—here's to thee, my fleſh tingles—

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: A word with you two Squiers.

sp.speaker: Wen.
sp.p: Any thing for a ſhelter, I foreſee a ſtorm; and what is one Cat among ſo many Maſtives?

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: You are melancholly.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: You lye, you that ſay nothing lye, if you be of his opinion.

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: Me thinks we are very merry.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: We are exceeding merry.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Have you diſcharg'd your Culvering? where's the paraquito?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I drunke it off.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: She is vaniſh'd too.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p:
Then we are our ſelves, and make me
your example; you know your Province Sirra, make ready for an Angell, ſing the deſigne of honour, and of fancy. Ex. boy.

lg.head: Song.
lg.l: But firſt in Phanſie we will foole,
Pull off our Dublets, drinke more coole,
Our hats upon our heads not ſtay,
For each health wee'l throw them away
So Periwig, or Fringe, or Border,
The naked truth wee'l drink in order.
And to the Muſick as they play
A Phanſie Peece wee'l throw away,
Ʋntill we are drein'd, can draw no more,
And the next day all cry therefore.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Off With Formalls Doublet, off with his Doublet, throw't into the fire, that's a good phanſic; now he is Formall right.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I did not drink hard, for I am cold, the wench would keep me warme, ſhe's a notable firedrake; will it pleaſe you ſir to go to the party?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Now does he betray what a Bawd he would be.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Does no body know where to get a Serpent with two legs that hath never a ſting?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I have a great mind to drink a health in one of my boots.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: I drink no beere glaſſes, if a ſhooe will ſerve turne—

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: His ſhooe, my ſcabberd, a match.

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: My glove.

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: His cap.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Fill brimmers, every man to his Miſtris; now do not I like this phanſie.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: We ha don't.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: There's wooll in my ſcabbard, which is a ſpungious matter, and when I ha done (Muſick Throne deſcends I may leave my drink behind me, and that's a hanging matter, which I am principally to avoid—Do you heare the Muſick of the Spheres Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: 1 Ieer.
sp.p: From the roofe a Throne?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: This roome is mine, and cald the field of Tempe; Becauſe I woonot ſtay while (The Wench peeps from under the Table. the Plaies are done when I have a humor to be merry, and drink healths in the clouds, I built this Eliſium; and when bright Sack hath crown'd my brow, how ſoon I am made immortall, you may gueſſe.

lg.head: A Song in the Throne.
lg.l: As I ſinging now came down,
I do bring you Bacchus Crown:
From the plumpe Lord of the vine
Cluſterd grapes to make you wine,
Your ſweld Temples circling in,
Crown'd with this, and bath'd within;
Therefore your beſt wiſhes bring,
Place this Garland on your King.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Is not Bacchus the beſt good fellow God on 'em all? Let me ſee, Formall ſhall be King, and he ſent to heaven preſently.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Send me to heaven? why ſhould I be ſent thither before another man?

sp.speaker: 2 Ieer.
sp.p: Ret, Ret, verily Ret, here's the Fartridge under the Table.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They'l be good company, they ſhall both be immortall together, helpe Gentlemen. Boy you muſt be depos'd.

sp.speaker: VVench.
sp.p: Alas what ſhall I doe?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: You ſhall to heaven Lady?

sp.speaker: VVench.
sp.p: What before my time? and whether I will or no?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: It ſhall be with as much eaſe, as if it were in a Featherbed.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Let us ſleepe together.

sp.speaker: VVench.
sp.p: Ah pitty a poore Gentlewoman, if you have hearts of fleſh, do not uſe me worſe than heathen Prentices.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: So crowne 'm, and give to each a glaſſe of wine, for a ſcepter.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Gentlewoman, if we muſt mount, 'tis none of our ſeeking, we are but Angells in our owne defence, for my owne part, I deſire to go thether in no better company.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Up with 'em, and preſerve your ſcepter glaſſes, doe not ſpill your blood royall.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Alas, hold there for heavens ſake, I muſt meet three Innes of court Gentlemen at the Stillyard to night, it may be out of my way 20. pound, conſider your owne caſes.

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Peace gentle Queene of grapes.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Thou art a traitor too, oh!

sp.speaker: For.
sp.p: Doe not jog the chariot, let us take our preſerment patiently, and drinke a health to the humble mortalls, that turne up their whites to us, this is pretty high drinking.

sp.speaker: Wench.
sp.p: Drunkards, divells? oh that I were upon earth agen.—

sp.speaker: 1 Jeer.
sp.p: Is this the Gentlewomans wine, or water?

sp.speaker: 2 Jeer.
sp.p: He mounts inſenſibly.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They have a heavenly time on't; you know me ſirra.

sp.speaker: Draw.
sp.p: Noble Mr. Newman.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: There's for your attendance.

sp.speaker: Jeer.
sp.p: What's to pay?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: They ſhall pay you the reckoning in the other world, you know the back way thither; come my boyes to the departed, having paid all rites
We now returne.

sp.speaker: Jeerers.
sp.p: Like woefull Adamites.

div.head: Act. V. Scaena. I.
div.stage: Enter Simpleton, James, (little Table ſet out.)

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: IAm reſolved, ſince faire meanes cannot prevaile with Miſtris Lucy, to ſteale her away, this is the key of the back-gate o'th' garden, to the fields, be ready when I give the ſigne to hurry her into the coach, and when I have her at my Countrey-Houſe, Ile take in her maiden towne, upon my owne compoſition.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: You wo'not raviſh her.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: There are twenty wayes to deale with a woman, and never raviſh her; no, I have plaid the foole too much.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: I am of your opinion.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: But ſhe ſhall find if I get poſſeſſion.—

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: The Coachman is a luſty fellow too, and will help to clap her abroad; the curtaines being cloſe ſhe cannot be heard, and the horſes will runne, as the devill were in the poope, for he drives like a Tamberlaine.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Holla ye pamperd Jades.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: One Traitour more were not amiſſe for al that.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Thou ſaiſt right, for though ſhe be a little woman, her voyce may be too ſtrong for us.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Let us alone, mind your owne part.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Be reſolute James. —Exit Simp.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: The courſe I am in, hath brought ſome men to the Gallowes, and doe I take it for prevention?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: What deſperate fellow's that?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I am weary of wine and noiſe, is there no other cure for melancholly? I doe not love the cramp in my necke.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: He lookes like a Gentleman that were in debt; my friend doe you come hither to finde a tree? th'art a proper fellow, doſt want employment, for though your cloathes have a good gloſſe, they looke as they were ill lin'd, they want money.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I ſuffer that which made the old woman mend her pace fir.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Doe as Ile direct thee.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Whom doe you ſerve?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: I ſerve my ſelfe; my Maſter is a foole; did you never heare of Simpleton?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: That worſhipfull puppy?

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: He knowes him. I have ſeen you before, but 'tis no matter where; I like thy countenance; can'ſt keepe counſell? walke o'this hand o'me.

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Nay a little further Miſtris Lucy, it ſeemes Mrs Ʋoluble told him no great good fortune, ſhe ſaw it in his ſtarres, for you know ſhe weares Aſtrology at her apron ſtrings; but ſhe told me in private who ſhould be the man, your deere Endymion.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Who I beſeech you?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: The object is preſented, and 'tis in vaine to oppoſe the Conſtellations, what muſt be muſt be, and there were no more Ladyes in the world, I am the man.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: To ſteale her away?

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: My Maſter is reſolv'd. They are here; cloſe.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: She is betraid.—

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Now.—

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Help; theeves.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Stop her mouth.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Then every man take his chance.

div.stage: (He ſtrikes downe Simpleton. Lucy runs eff.)

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: Murther, murther.

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Are you ſo cunning ſir? you ſhall along with us. (They diſarme New.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Worried by Hedghogs!

sp.speaker: Ja.
sp.p: Are you not kill'd outright ſir?

sp.speaker: Sim.
sp.p: I am not certaine, be ſure you hold him faſt; to the next Juſtice; I muſt get a Surgeon. You are my rivall, I know you well enough, if I miſcarry, it ſhall coſt me a hundred pound, but Ile ha thee hang'd for't. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: I underſtand you perfectly Miſtris Voluble, and like your propoſition; but a word more of the widdow that is at your' houſe, ſhee is very rich you ſay?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Not in underſtanding.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Tis the better.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Her's all your worſhip muſt promiſe her, to be knighted, for ſhe hath a great mind to bee a Lady.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: I know where a blanck lies dormant for a Baronet, it will carry more noiſe and authority on the bench too.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: You have done me ſome diſcourteſie here tofore, in beleeving the complaints of Intemperate tongues againſt me, but you ſee my charity I deſire to live in your worſhips faire opinion 〈◊〉 a neighbour.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p:
I will make you amends ſweet Miſtris V •
luable, y'are a vertuous Gentlewoman on my conſcience: but how ſhall this widdow be wrought?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p:
Thats done already. The truth is ſhe inquir'd
of me, (for we women uſe to open our ſecrets one to another) for ſome ſtayd Gentleman that was a Lawier, (becauſe ſhe has ſo great an eſtate, and many ſutes to follow) on whom ſhee might beſtow her ſelfe, for the ſecurity of her fortune, and I have already prepared her, and ſuch a commendation of your perſon, and learned gravity, a Juſtice of Peace and Quorum, out of my private reſpects to you, without deſire or expectation of any bribe or reward.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: I underſtand that very well.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: I know you doe.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: How much I am bound to your vertue?

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: The widdow has a great mind to ſee you, but I will contrive it for your honour, ſhee ſhall come hither, as to her learned Counſell.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: The invincible wit of a woman! how I honour it.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: There can bee no loſſe in't if you get a Chaplaine in readineſſe, widowes are taken in the opportunitie.

sp.speaker: Rich.
sp.p: A Gentleman brought to be examined, that has wounded one Maſter Simpleton.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Simpleton? that's the widowes ſon.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Richard, ſend to the Curate of the Pariſh, ſay I would ſpeake with him preſently.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Alas who hurt you?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: My rivall Maſter Newman, Is this the • uſtice?

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p:
A former quarrell; if you die, I have • aw
enough to make it murther, for your good Mothers ſake.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: Cannot you make it manſlaughter, and let me live? for I deſire but his death.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Hee ſhall make it what you pleaſe. This Gentleman is to bee Knighted, and loves your mother above all the world, things meet as cloſe, as if they went to engender.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: My Mother is worth ſix thouſand pound, if you will promiſe to make her a Lady, and doe your beſt to hang the Gentleman, you ſhall be my Father in Law, when my Landlady ſayes the word.

sp.speaker: Vol.
sp.p: Sir Ile take my leave.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Sweet Miſtris Voluble, leave your friend to me, I underſtand the matter perfectly, and it ſhall goe hard, but wee will have all the Law on our ſide. Call in the offender; pleaſe you ſit; Richard be ready with your Ammunition, Pen, Inke and Paper.

div.stage: Enter Surgeon, Newman, Iames, Coachman, Conſtable and officers.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: VVhat is your name ſir?

sp.speaker: Surg.
sp.p: My name is Seare.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: He is the Surgeon ſir.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Ile teach you • o follow your profeſſion ſirra, Ile make you an example to all Phlebotomers; how often have you beene indited for letting of blood firra?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: I underſtand you nor.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p:
But I underſtand you ſirra; how durſt you vi & armis, felloniouſly aſſault this noble Gentleman in contempt of peice, and the Kings Law,
his Crowne and dignity? anſwer me ſirra to that. Ile ſeeze him.

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: You VVorſhip is miſtaken, I never ſee the Gentleman before, I was ſent for—

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: He is the Surgeon ſir, that is come to take meaſure of my Maſters wounds, it was that Gentleman that let him blood.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: VVhy do they not change faces then? away you knave, and looke to the Gentleman; you ſtand idling here to ſtumble authority with a fellonious countenance.

sp.speaker: Ia.
sp.p: Let us be for ſworne both in a tale.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Sir, you are one that ſhould doe Juſtice; where is my poore friend? bee not ſo much dejected, you did but reſcue me ſir from diſhonour.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I was in a melancholly humour; 'tis come about as the wiſe woman concluded.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: VVher's Simpleton? I may accuſe him for a Rape.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Take heede what you ſay.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Or ſome ſuch black intent; this Gentleman but interpos'd to ſave me from their ſurie, and with his ſword puniſh'd a bold offender by letting out ſome blood that was corrupted.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Thats not materiall; will you confeſſe you wounded Maſter Simpleton? come to the matter.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I confeſſe it ſir, but heare the reaſon.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p:
I will heare no reaſon, that were ſimple juſtice; take him aſide, and you may follow your
buſineſſe. Stay young Gentlewoman, I muſt examine you.

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: Shall I withdraw, and ſhut the doore?

div.stage: Exeunt all but Iuſtice and Lucie.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: VVhat Juſtice • ir, or Law is this?

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: It is not Polton, Crompton, nor Fitzerhert, A Juſtice ought to have ſome diſcretion without booke, eſpecially in theſe caſes. I grant you are the root and cauſe of this misfortune.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I • ir?

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Be wiſe, and underſtand me; nd being indued with ſuch gifts of nature, native beauty and favour, (come a little nearer) and you to abuſe your ſelfe—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How ſir?

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Or ſuffer your ſelfe to be abuſed (come a little nearer) is not to be thankefull for thoſe excellent benefits.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: VVill you tranſlate an Inſolence in others upon my guilt?

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p:
You accuſe an honeſt Gentleman for an intent of rape; alas poore ſoule, it was pure affection in him, hee would have raviſhed you no doubt, with your owne conſent, the fault was your Ingratitude, (a little nearer) Seneca doth write much of Ingratitude, that I may come (a little nearer) or elſe Nero had not let him blood, (yet nearer) this Nero was a moſt wicked Tyrant, for all he could play upon a fidle, make ballads, and ſing them himſelfe, and therefore take heede of cruelty, and be gentle, he kiſſ • th her.
• or, ſweet-heart Nero died a violent death.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: My Mother.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Lucy you made haſte.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: Your pardon Madam.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: I underſtand ſhe is a Lady.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: In the defence of my owne vertue, and the noble Gentleman that ſuffers for his charity to me—

sp.speaker: Beauf.
sp.p: I came to aſſiſt you. It were an injurie to doubt your juſtice. My name is Beaufield. If my credit may be interpos'd ſecurity for Newman my daughters knowledge in the cauſe will Enter Clarke. give a moſt cleare ſatisfaction.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Richard, call in the delinquent, this Lady has ſpoken very much to the matter, as I underſtand it. Has the Surgeon done yet?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p: They are comming downe.

div.stage: Ent • r Surgeon, Newman, Simpleton, Iames, Conſtable, Officers.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Now ſir, how many of his wounds are mortall?

sp.speaker: Sur.
sp.p: There is not one conſiderable, the Gentleman is in no danger.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: But have not you authority to hang him? Ile take my oath, he had an intent to kill me. My Lady and Miſtris Lucie? Iames, Ile ſtay no longer, ſince I am not mortally wounded, ſneake after me.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: My hanging • it is over, and the witchcraft, I am now my ſelfe again, if you can pardon Enter Manley. me Madam this too great an honour to your worthleſſe ſervant.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: How now? what ſaucie fellow's this?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Shee's here too. I am bold Cozen to viſit you, they ſay, ther's a Gentleman brought before you, for breach o'th' peace, I come to baile him.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: We take no forrainers; what outlandiſh thing are you, pray?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You know me ſir, my name is Manley, you ca • ld me cozen yeſterday.

sp.speaker: Luſt.
sp.p: I never ſaw you before. I know that name, and a Gentleman that ownes it, a kinſman of mine too, but he is no ſuch Brandemart. Richard, doe you know this Mahound? he calls himſelfe my cozen Manly.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Why in this habit?

sp.speaker: Iuſt
sp.p: Tranſmigration?

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Is it not ſome ſpie • ir?

sp.speaker: Iuſt
sp.p: Conſtable take him to your charge. Ile teach you ſirra, to uſurpe a Gentlemans name; tis fellony ipſo facto, write his mittimus.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: By what ſtatute? Trigeſimo Secundo of King Phillip? I doe not Madam deſire your cer • ificate.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Y'ar • a ſtranger ſir to me, yet I dare bee engag'd for his forth comming, hee has an honeſt face.

sp.speaker: Man
sp.p: Come hither Richard, theres halfe a peece, rub thy eyes woo't, are they open yet?

sp.speaker: Clar.
sp.p:
I ſee you plainely now • ir, y'are my Maſters
cozen, 'tis Maſter Manley.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: 'Tis your beſt courſe to owne me too; is it ſo long ſince you tooke bribes, ſince you divided and manumisd a crooked chambermaid that robd her Miſtris of old Gold? there was a Lancepreſado ſtript a hedge, when you were out of Linnen; Peuter has been left at the back-doore, when you did ſtudy Alchymie; I leave the tricke you ſhew'd the Sailors wife in your Cloſet, when you promis'd a reprieve to her goodman from Wapping; I know not that you have run your wither'd motley face into a prem • nire; doe not know me, why d'ee no • charge the conſtable?

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: What is a Juſtice without eyes, I meane ſpectacles? 'tis he indeed, I underſtand, and ſee him perfectly; welcome, a Chaire for my Coſen?

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: So then. Madam a word with you, I'le make you know me too, ere I ha' done.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: There is a matted Chamber & a Couch—More buſineſſe?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Vere is de matre Juſtice? begar dey have put de ſheare upon me, me expect de riſh vidow, and have marry the chambermaid, ſhe confeſſe dat, Maitre Juſtice, pray take her to your ſelfe, me deſire your varrant, for Metreſſe Ʋoluble, dat ſhe bring the vidow Simplaton to marry me ſans ceremoine, dat is your commiſſion, or begar me complaine of you to de King.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: Did you expect the rich widow Simpleton? h • , ha! I know this trifle, my Clarke knowes her better

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Bergar Matre Juſtice, and Matre Clarke make your diviſion, dat is all you ſee.

sp.speaker: Nice.
sp.p: Sir I have onely cauſe to complaine, he told me he was a French Lord, Miſtris Ʋoluble ſhall make affidavit, and courted me to be his Lady, and now we are married, he proves but a cinquepace. I look'd for thouſands per annum, and he is but one, two, three, foure, and five.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: How, did he pretend himſelfe to be a Lord? 'tis Scandalum Magnatum in the higheſt degree: and by a ſtatute quinquageſimo of the Queene, if ſhe proſecute, he is to be whip'd, and loſe his eares three ſeverall market dayes.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: How will you divide his Eares into three equall portions?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Me give a de whip, and me Ioſe a mine 'ares!

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: You heare the law, if I complaine.

sp.speaker: I. Ieer.
sp.p: Sir—Miſtris Ʋoluble—

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Is the widow come?

sp.speaker: I Ieer.
sp.p: The Gentlewoman is come, and deſires to ſpeake with your worſhip in private.

sp.speaker: Cla.
sp.p: The Curat's in the Hall ſir.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: So, ſo, I muſt intreate your patience for a few minutes; how I am bleſt! Exit.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Tell a me de trot, have you no Argent, no portion?

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: But I have a trade.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I dare be ſworne thou haſt.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Aw dat is ſometing, here is my hand, you no tell a de tale, a me, and me keepe your Enter Sir William, and Mother.
ſecret by my trot.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I tooke boldneſſe Madam upon ſight of your Ladiſhips new Coach at the doore, to entrude and preſent a poore forſaken ſervant; give you joy of your old faſhion'd young Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Your companion wants no antiquity, if ſhe have no Viſard on.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: I hope you are not married Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: The matters done, and tis more honourable to make a Lady than to marry one. Does any body know this Gentlewoman, ſhe was a widow till this morning, and a rich one I thanke my ſtaires, and wants the ſubtile art, ſome Ladyes have to make themſelves ridiculous, by doting upon anticks.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: What name has your moſt reverend Lady?

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: She was called the wealthy widow of old Simpleton, before I married her.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: What Is't makes you ſo merry Mounſieur?

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Begar ſome body make arrant aſſe of de Knight, hold a me, or me ſhall cracke a my rib wi'de laugh, dat is no Simplaton, but an autre Chambermaid, de ſervant to my vife, begar he be ſheated too.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: I muſt confeſſe ſhe waited upon me.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Ma foy dat is certaine, ha, ha, ha!

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: I deſie her, that was but a plot.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p:
Begar it was very fine a plot, me have
patience, dat dere be more foole in de comedy.

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Miſtris Ʋoluble can juſtifie what I am, that I am, or would I might nere be, a Lady, and I be'nt, that I be'nt.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: I will have Juſtice.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: You may have him ſir.

sp.speaker: Iuſtice
sp.p: The reaſon of this noyſe my right worſhipfull?

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: Give me a warrant preſently.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Againſt whom?

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: Ʋol • ble, I'le have her whip'd.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: Wrong not the vertuous Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: Vertuous? vexation.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Why doe you take on ſo, o' my conſcience ſhe is honeſt enough; does this woman looke like a whore?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: I thanke you Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: She has gravity enough to be a bawde, and then the worſt is paſt.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Is not the widow weight, not perfect ſterling?

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: This is not the widow.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: What widow?

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: The rich widow Simpleton.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: I doe believe it, did ſhe promiſe you marriage?

sp.speaker: Sir VVil.
sp.p: The devills proctor Miſtris Ʋoluble made me believe ſo.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p:
Doe not wrong I ſay agen that vertuous Gentlewoman Miſtris Ʋoluble, I know her, and know her vertuous, but the rich widow Simpleton, you talke of (thankes be to providence) is
newly married, the Prieſt hath ſcarce wip'd his oraculous lips, ſince they pronounc'd us, Man Enter Ʋoluble, and two Ieerers (at one doore) Simpleton, at the other.) and Wife, in my ſtone Parlour, in good faith la, ſhe's here, her owne tongue will confirme it Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Why does ſhe veile her face.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: It is her modeſty, to hide her bluſhes, that I ſhould ſo ſoone prevaile upon her: and thus the morning breakes out of the cloudes.

sp.speaker: • impl.
sp.p: By your leave Landlady, wher's my mother.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Miſtris Ʋoluble?

sp.speaker: Moth.
sp.p: Here's my ſon, he ſhall be a witneſſe I am his mother, I am married to this Knight, and they would perſwade me out of my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: 'Tis come about agen, Is this your mother?

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I have asked her bleſſing in my dayes.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: There is no remedy, 'twas your owne Curate did it.

sp.speaker: Ieer
sp.p: Give you joy Mr. Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Conſpiracy, is there no law for this?

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Yes, yes, the canon law, and you muſt keepe her.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: Let me obtaine Madam your faire conſtruction, Sir William you are ſped to your deſires, and you are fitted Mounſieur Galliard, but Nice, the Jewells muſt returne to their right owner.

sp.speaker: Gal.
sp.p: Excuſe a moy.

sp.speaker: Ni.
sp.p: It muſt be ſo, I keepe my wedding ring for thee ſweet heart.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p:
I aske you pardon ſir, and Miſtris Lucy,
I had a plot upon your loves, to endeare young Simpleton, in hope your credulous nature, to avoid melancholy, might have beene engag'd to ſome licentious rudeneſſe, and ſo made your ſelf unworthy of her affection, but here I muſt confeſſe I have no skill in ſtarres nor fortune telling, and am but one among the reſt that have deceiv'd your eaſy faith, forgive me, as I wiſh you may thrive in your affections.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: I am confirm'd.

sp.speaker: Beau.
sp.p: Nay then let marriages goe round, with this take both poſſeſſion of my heart and fortunes.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: You but inlarge my power to doe you ſervice.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Your love, and joyes be conſtant. Mr. Iuſtice you muſt embrace Miſtris Ʋoluble.

sp.speaker: Iu.
sp.p: VVell, I will love thee for thy wit; but no more wandring.

sp.speaker: Ʋol.
sp.p: You wholly ſir ſhall ſteere me, and to invite more welcome from you ſir, I have not liv'd upon the common charity, I have a ſtate is not to be deſpis'd.

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p: Saiſt thou ſo, wee'l put our ſtocks together and live merrily.

sp.speaker: New.
sp.p: Will they not take his word? alas poore Formall, there, there's their ranſome, bid the whore be honeſt, I'le plead his reconcilement to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Ieere Ma.
sp.p: I am gone.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: But d'ee heare, muſt I ha' no wench, at the end of the play? that have taken all this paines? what will you doe with me?

sp.speaker: Iuſt.
sp.p:
Well remembred, this Lady did accuſe
him; though I miſſ'd of the Mother, I will make ſure of the ſon, make his warrant for Newgate preſently.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: How Sir?

sp.speaker: Clark.
sp.p: I know how very well Sir.

sp.speaker: Lu.
sp.p: You call'd it love before, I freely pardon him.

sp.speaker: Sir Wil.
sp.p: Let this Day be conſecrate to peace, and Hymen.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.p: And the Night to Ʋenus; let it be ſo, and thanke this Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Simp.
sp.p: I thanke you all, and will never truſt a witch for your ſake, I'le goe ſeeke out my wits.

sp.speaker: Juſt.
sp.l: Let no man part, ſo many hearts here tid'd,
Stay till we drinke a health to every Bride.
